threat_actors.original_title: Mustang Panda deploys ToneShell via signed kernel-mode rootkit driver
threat_actors.content_snippet: China-linked APT Mustang Panda used a signed kernel-mode rootkit driver to load shellcode and deploy its ToneShell backdoor. China-linked APT Mustang Panda (aka Hive0154, HoneyMyte, Camaro Dragon, RedDelta or Bronze President) was observed using a signed kernel-mode rootkit driver with embedded shel...
tools: malicious driver signed with Guangzhou Kingteller certificate
techniques: raw TCP C2 with fake TLS 1.3
attack_patterns: Filter driver manipulation to evade detection
procedures: install mini-filter driver ProjectConfiguration.sys
protect driver via callbacks
intercept operations before antivirus
disable Microsoft Defender WdFilter
spawn svchost and inject delay shellcode
inject ToneShell payload
remove traces after execution
known_iocs: driver file signed with certificate serial 08 01 CC 11 EB 4D 1D 33 1E 3D 54 0C 55 A4 9F 7F
registry key altering WdFilter altitude to 0
raw TCP communication on port 443 with fake TLS 1.3 headers
hashed API values used for resolution
threat_actors.impact_assessment: high
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce strict driver signing policies and whitelist only trusted certificates
Monitor kernel-mode drivers and filter driver altitude changes
Block execution of unsigned kernel drivers
Use EDR solutions that monitor kernel API calls and driver installations
Inspect registry for alterations to WdFilter altitude
Detect anomalous raw TCP traffic on port 443 with non-standard TLS characteristics
Apply network segmentation and restrict outbound connections to known C2 endpoints
Regularly scan for indicator files such as ProjectConfiguration.sys and C:\ProgramData\MicrosoftOneDrive.tlb
Patch and update security software to reduce filter driver bypass opportunities
references: Kaspersky report on signed kernel driver

threat_actors.name: Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) Insider Group
threat_actors.title: Dismantling Defenses: Trump 2.0 Cyber Year in Review
threat_actors.original_title: Dismantling Defenses: Trump 2.0 Cyber Year in Review
threat_actors.content_snippet: The Trump administration has pursued a staggering range of policy pivots this past year that threaten to weaken the nation’s ability and willingness to address a broad spectrum of technology challenges, from cybersecurity and privacy to countering disinformation, fraud and corruption. These sh...
primary_objectives: Exfiltrate sensitive personal and governmental data
Surveil federal communications for anti‑Trump sentiment
tactics: Bypass of security monitoring and incident response controls
Use of AI tools to aggregate and analyze harvested data
Leveraging external compromised credentials (e.g., Russian IP logins)
procedures: Provision short‑lived accounts with minimal audit trails
Download gigabytes of agency case files using standard OS utilities
Transfer data to external storage via encrypted channels
Run AI/ML models to synthesize cross‑agency datasets
Mask activity by routing traffic through compromised Russian IP addresses
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Massive breach of personal data of U.S. citizens and sensitive government information, increased risk of foreign exploitation, erosion of public trust, and potential national security ramifications.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict least‑privilege access controls and regular privilege reviews
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for all privileged accounts
Deploy UEBA (User and Entity Behavior Analytics) to detect anomalous account creation and usage
Audit and log all privileged account activity with immutable storage
Segment sensitive data stores and restrict cross‑agency data flows
Establish robust insider‑threat detection and response programs
Monitor for external login attempts from high‑risk geographies and block unauthorized access
Apply data loss prevention (DLP) solutions to monitor large data transfers
Restrict use of external AI services for processing classified or sensitive data
references: Krebsonsecurity, "Dismantling Defenses: Trump 2.0 Cyber Year in Review", 2025-12-19
KrebsOnSecurity article citing anonymous researcher NatInfoSec
Reuters report on DOGE data access
NPR coverage of federal citizen database

Monitor for anomalous credential usage and fund transfers

threat_actors.title: Lazarus Group Embed New BeaverTail Variant in Developer Tools
threat_actors.original_title: Lazarus Group Embed New BeaverTail Variant in Developer Tools
threat_actors.content_snippet: North Korea’s Lazarus Group deploys a new BeaverTail variant to steal credentials and crypto using fake job lures, dev tools, and smart contracts.
tactics: Social engineering via fake job postings
Embedding malicious code in smart contracts
procedures: Distribute malicious BeaverTail variant through compromised npm packages
Inject backdoor code into legitimate developer tool installers
Use fake recruitment emails to deliver malicious payloads
Deploy malicious smart contracts to harvest crypto assets
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High impact due to large‑scale credential theft, direct cryptocurrency theft, and potential compromise of software supply chains affecting downstream users.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict validation of third‑party developer tool packages and use signed binaries.
Enforce multi‑factor authentication and credential hygiene for all accounts.
Monitor for anomalous smart contract deployments and blockchain transaction patterns.
Conduct security awareness training focusing on fake job lure and recruitment phishing.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions with behavior‑based detection for BeaverTail signatures.
references: HackRead article: Lazarus Group Embed New BeaverTail Variant in Developer Tools (2025-12-18)
FireEye report: Lazarus Group – APT38 Activity (2024)

threat_actors.name: Unknown cybercriminal group (GhostPairing actors)
threat_actors.title: The ghosts of WhatsApp: How GhostPairing hijacks accounts
threat_actors.original_title: The ghosts of WhatsApp: How GhostPairing hijacks accounts
threat_actors.content_snippet: Researchers have found an active campaign aimed at taking over WhatsApp accounts. They’ve called this attack GhostPairing because it tricks the victim into completing WhatsApp’s own device-pairing flow, silently adding the attacker’s browser as an invisible linked device on the account. Ghost ...
primary_objectives: Harvest messages, media, and personal data
Conduct fraud, social engineering, and extortion
Spread malicious links to further compromise contacts
tools: Browser automation scripts to register linked devices
tactics: Use of fake login pages mimicking Meta services
techniques: User Execution – clicking malicious QR code or numeric code (T1204)
attack_patterns: Account takeover via legitimate pairing flow
Credential phishing using fake Meta login
procedures: Send a message claiming a photo has been found, containing a malicious link
Host a counterfeit Meta‑styled login page that asks for the victim’s phone number
Submit the phone number to WhatsApp’s device‑pairing API to generate a QR code or numeric code
Convince the victim to scan the QR code or enter the numeric code in WhatsApp, thereby linking the attacker’s browser as a hidden device
Use the linked device to read, download, and send messages, and to propagate the lure to contacts
victimology: Business or professional accounts using WhatsApp for communication
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Compromise of personal and possibly business communications, data exfiltration, fraud, and further propagation of social‑engineering scams; can remain undetected for extended periods.
mitigation_recommendations: Do not click unsolicited links, even from trusted contacts; verify with the sender
Enable WhatsApp Two‑Step Verification (PIN)
Regularly review and revoke unknown linked devices in Settings → Linked Devices
Educate users about the legitimate WhatsApp pairing process and warning signs of fake QR‑code or numeric code prompts
Implement email/SMiShing filters to block known phishing domains
Monitor for anomalous WhatsApp activity and rapid message forwarding patterns
references: Malwarebytes, “The ghosts of WhatsApp: How GhostPairing hijacks accounts”, 2025-12-18

Rotate URLs and storage buckets to evade detection

Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) with web protection

threat_actors.name: Scotaibank Typosquatting Actor
threat_actors.title: Most Parked Domains Now Serving Malicious Content
threat_actors.original_title: Most Parked Domains Now Serving Malicious Content
threat_actors.content_snippet: Direct navigation — the act of visiting a website by manually typing a domain name in a web browser — has never been riskier: A new study finds the vast majority of “parked” domains — mostly expired or dormant domain names, or common misspellings of popular websites &#8...
malware_families: Information stealers delivered via malicious redirects
tactics: Domain parking with malicious ad networks
Chain of redirects with device fingerprinting
techniques: T1566.001 Phishing: Spearphishing via malicious redirect
attack_patterns: Malicious redirect chain to scam landing pages
Business Email Compromise (BEC) using typo‑domain email addresses
procedures: Register typo domains (e.g., scotaibank.com, gmai.com, ic3.org)
Configure placeholder parking pages that sell clicks to advertisers
Set up mail server on typo domains to capture email traffic
Chain redirects through multiple parking/affiliate domains before delivering final payload
Profile visitor via IP geolocation, device fingerprinting, and cookies to tailor redirect
victimology: Users typing popular domain names incorrectly
Employees of targeted organizations receiving BEC emails
known_iocs: example typo domains: craigslists.com, youtbe.com, googl.com, wikipdia.org, netflx.com, tripadviser.com, yaho.com, ebay.com, microsoft.com
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High – victims may experience credential theft, financial loss from scams, malware infection, and reputational damage from BEC incidents.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement DNS filtering to block known typo‑squatting domains
Encourage use of VPNs or secure DNS resolvers for residential traffic
Register and monitor common typo variants of own brand domains
Deploy DMARC, SPF, and DKIM to protect against BEC using typo domains
Educate users about risks of typing URLs manually and checking HTTPS certificates
Monitor web traffic for unusual redirect chains and affiliate traffic patterns
Use threat intelligence feeds that include typo‑squatting IOCs
references: KrebsOnSecurity article "Most Parked Domains Now Serving Malicious Content" (2025-12-16)

threat_actors.name: PayPal Subscription Scam Group
threat_actors.title: PayPal closes loophole that let scammers send real emails with fake purchase notices
threat_actors.original_title: PayPal closes loophole that let scammers send real emails with fake purchase notices
threat_actors.content_snippet: After an investigation by BleepingComputer, PayPal closed a loophole that allowed scammers to send emails from the legitimate service@paypal.com email address. Following reports from people who received emails claiming an automatic payment had been cancelled, BleepingComputer found that cybercrimina...
tools: Remote desktop utilities (e.g., TeamViewer, AnyDesk, custom RAT)
tactics: Email spoofing using legitimate sender address
techniques: T1071.003 Application Layer Protocol: Web Services
T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application (abuse of PayPal subscription pause feature)
T1059 Command and Scripting Interpreter (remote command execution via victim’s PC)
T1021 Remote Services (use of remote desktop tools)
attack_patterns: Email phishing using a trusted sender address
procedures: Create a PayPal merchant subscription for a fake product
Pause the subscription to trigger PayPal’s automatic‑payment‑cancelled notification
Configure a Google Workspace mailing list to auto‑forward the notification to many recipients
Insert a fake “PayPal Support” phone number and urgent language to induce panic
When victim calls, convince them to grant remote desktop access
Deploy RATs or fake security tools to harvest credentials and install additional malware
victimology: Small businesses using PayPal for recurring billing
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Victims may lose money through fraudulent charges, have credentials compromised, and suffer additional malware infection via remote‑access scams. Reputational damage to PayPal and erosion of trust in legitimate subscription notifications.
mitigation_recommendations: Educate users to verify PayPal notifications via the official app or website
Enable two‑factor authentication on PayPal accounts
Block or flag emails that originate from service@paypal.com but contain suspicious content or unexpected attachments/links
Disallow automatic forwarding from generic mailing lists for security‑sensitive communications
Never grant remote desktop access to unsolicited callers
Monitor for unusual subscription activity in PayPal merchant dashboards
Implement email authentication (DMARC, SPF, DKIM) and anomaly detection for outbound PayPal messages
references: Malwarebytes article “PayPal closes loophole that let scammers send real emails with fake purchase notices”

procedures: targeting third‑party service providers
exfiltration of data via encrypted channels
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Exfiltration of personal data of 5.6 million individuals, creating a high risk of identity theft and fraud.
mitigation_recommendations: Deploy a Web Application Firewall (WAF) and keep it updated
Patch web applications and underlying frameworks promptly
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for all privileged and user accounts
Segment networks to isolate sensitive data stores
Implement continuous monitoring and anomaly detection for data exfiltration
Conduct regular security assessments and penetration testing of third‑party integrations

threat_actors.name: Unnamed Turkish cybercriminal group
threat_actors.title: Frogblight threatens you with a court case: a new Android banker targets Turkish users
threat_actors.original_title: Frogblight threatens you with a court case: a new Android banker targets Turkish users
threat_actors.content_snippet: In August 2025, we discovered a campaign targeting individuals in Turkey with a new Android banking Trojan we dubbed “Frogblight”. Initially, the malware was disguised as an app for accessing court case files via an official government webpage. Later, more universal disguises appeared, s...
tactics: Smishing (SMS phishing) to deliver malicious APKs
Masquerading as legitimate apps (court case viewer, Chrome browser)
Use of legitimate government webpages as WebView intermediaries
Command and Control via REST API and WebSocket
Persistence through boot receivers, scheduled jobs, foreground services
Accessibility service abuse to prevent removal and inject UI
Emulator and geolocation checks for evasion
techniques: T1059.003 Command and Control: Web Services (REST API)
T1071.001 Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols (WebSocket)
T1547.001 Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder (Android boot receiver)
T1543.003 Create or Modify System Process: Services
T1546.012 Event Triggered Execution: Accessibility Service
attack_patterns: SMS interception and sending arbitrary SMS
Bulk SMS spam campaigns from compromised devices
procedures: Distribute malicious APKs via SMS links claiming court case involvement
Host phishing landing pages on Vercel with source code publicly available on GitHub
Rename app icon and label based on Android version to blend in
Inject JavaScript into WebView to capture banking credentials
Send captured data to C2 using Retrofit‑based REST calls every 2 seconds
Switch to WebSocket C2 in later versions for real‑time command execution
Provide MaaS (Malware‑as‑a‑Service) portal for attackers to control infected devices
victimology: Users who interact with Turkish government court portals
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful infections lead to theft of banking credentials, unauthorized financial transactions, privacy breaches (SMS, contacts, files), and potential monetary loss for victims. The malware also enables attackers to send bulk SMS, increasing spam and fraud risk.
mitigation_recommendations: Educate users about smishing and verify SMS links before downloading apps
Enforce installation of apps only from trusted app stores; block side‑loading of unknown APKs
Implement mobile threat defense solutions that detect suspicious permissions and behavior
Network‑level blocking of known C2 domains/IPs and suspicious outbound traffic to unknown hosts
Use Mobile Device Management (MDM) to restrict accessibility services and prevent unknown apps from gaining privileged permissions
Monitor for abnormal SMS sending patterns and unexpected contacts or call log changes
Regularly audit installed applications and remove unused apps with extensive permissions
Apply runtime application self‑protection (RASP) or sandboxing for banking apps
references: Securelist article: "Frogblight threatens you with a court case: a new Android banker targets Turkish users" (2025-12-15)

threat_actors.title: Following the digital trail: what happens to data stolen in a phishing attack
threat_actors.original_title: Following the digital trail: what happens to data stolen in a phishing attack
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction A typical phishing attack involves a user clicking a fraudulent link and entering their credentials on a scam website. However, the attack is far from over at that point. The moment the confidential information falls into the hands of cybercriminals, it immediately transforms into a com...
primary_objectives: facilitation of secondary attacks (e.g., account takeover, fraud)
tools: Discord servers used as data repositories
tactics: credential phishing via cloned login pages
use of disposable Telegram bots for real‑time exfiltration
centralized administration panels for campaign management
selling data dumps on dark‑web marketplaces
re‑using old credentials for targeted whaling attacks
techniques: T1059 – Command‑and‑Control via Telegram Bot API
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1585 – Establish Accounts (admin panels, bot accounts)
attack_patterns: Whaling attacks leveraging previously harvested personal data
procedures: Deploy PHP‑based phishing kits that forward credentials to a hard‑coded email address or Telegram bot token
Configure commercial phishing frameworks (BulletProofLink, Caffeine) to aggregate data in a unified dashboard
Export harvested credentials in CSV/JSON for bulk sale
Validate credentials automatically (card checks, login verification) before listing
Bundle disparate data points (email, password, phone) into a single dossier for resale
known_iocs: Common phishing kit file names: index.php, mail.php, next.php
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High – stolen credentials enable direct financial theft, account takeover, and further targeted attacks, potentially affecting millions of users and leading to significant monetary loss and reputational damage.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce multi‑factor authentication on all accounts
Deploy anti‑phishing email gateways and URL filtering
Educate users on credential reuse risks and phishing indicators
Implement credential‑leak detection services to monitor for exposed credentials
Restrict outbound traffic to Telegram API only for approved services
Regularly audit and rotate privileged service accounts used for data collection
references: Securelist – "Following the digital trail: what happens to data stolen in a phishing attack" (2025-12-12)

threat_actors.original_title: DroidLock malware locks you out of your Android device and demands ransom
threat_actors.content_snippet: Researchers have analyzed a new threat campaign actively targeting Android users. The malware, named DroidLock, takes over a device and then holds it for ransom. tactics: abuse of Device Admin and Accessibility Services
techniques: T1546.008 Event Triggered Execution: Accessibility Services
procedures: Host malicious website that mimics legitimate telecom or brand pages
Prompt user to download and install a fake app
Social engineer victim to grant Device Admin and Accessibility permissions
Use Accessibility overlays to capture unlock patterns and credentials
Establish VNC session for real‑time remote control
Lock device, change PIN, display ransom note with 24‑hour deadline
victimology: users who install apps from untrusted links
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Victims lose access to their devices, risk of data exfiltration, possible financial loss from ransom payment, and potential compromise of OTPs and other credentials.
mitigation_recommendations: Install apps only from official app stores
Verify developer reputation, download counts, and user reviews before installing
Avoid granting Device Admin or Accessibility permissions to unknown apps
Use up‑to‑date mobile anti‑malware solutions (e.g., Malwarebytes for Android)
Keep Android OS, Google Play services, and apps patched
Educate users about phishing links and fake app downloads
Monitor for unusual permission changes or VNC services on devices

threat_actors.original_title: GhostFrame phishing kit fuels widespread attacks against millions
threat_actors.content_snippet: GhostFrame is a new phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) kit, tracked since September 2025, that has already powered more than a million phishing attacks. Threat analysts spotted a series of phishing attacks featuring tools and techniques they hadn’t seen before. A few months later, they had linked o...
tactics: Use of malicious iframes for stealth (T1059.001)
Anti‑analysis techniques (disable right‑click, block dev tools)
Embedding login forms within image/large‑file streams
techniques: T1059.001 – Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell (used for subdomain generation)
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1027 – Obfuscated Files or Information (iframe obfuscation)
T1564.001 – Hide Artifacts: Hidden Files and Directories (iframe content)
T1564.004 – Hide Artifacts: Hide Artifacts in Web Traffic
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting via forged Microsoft 365 login pages
Stealth delivery using rotating subdomains and iframe embedding
procedures: Generate a unique subdomain per victim and rotate it during the session
Load malicious login page inside an iframe that mimics legitimate content
Adjust page titles and favicons to match the impersonated brand
Disable right‑click and common keyboard shortcuts to hinder analysis
Interfere with browser developer tools to prevent inspection
Serve fake login forms as image or BLOB streams to evade static scanners
victimology: Employees of organizations using cloud productivity suites (e.g., Microsoft 365)
Individuals receiving unsolicited email or messaging links
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft affecting millions of users, leading to account takeover, data exfiltration, and possible resale of compromised credentials on underground markets.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce multi‑factor authentication (MFA) for all accounts
Use password managers to avoid credential reuse
Educate users to verify unsolicited links before clicking
Deploy anti‑phishing browser extensions (e.g., Malwarebytes Browser Guard)
Implement URL filtering to block dynamically generated subdomains associated with known PhaaS kits
Monitor for unusual iframe activity and subdomain churn in web traffic logs
Enable strict Content Security Policy (CSP) to restrict iframe sources
Conduct regular phishing simulation exercises
references: Malwarebytes article: "GhostFrame phishing kit fuels widespread attacks against millions" (2025-12-10)

threat_actors.original_title: FinCEN data shows $4.5B in ransomware payments, record spike in 2023
threat_actors.content_snippet: Ransomware payments reported to FinCEN exceeded $4.5B by 2024, with 2023 marking a record year at $1.1B across 1,512 incidents. FinCEN analyzed ransomware trends using Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) reports filed from January 2022 to February 2025. During this period, organizations reported 4,194 ransomware...
procedures: Deploy ransomware payload via malicious email attachments or compromised remote services
Encrypt victim files and append ransom note
Leak exfiltrated data on public leak sites if ransom not paid
Facilitate payment through Bitcoin mixers and CVC exchanges
victimology: Enterprises of medium to large size
Organizations handling sensitive financial or health data
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Responsible for approximately $395.3 million in ransomware payments during the 2022‑2025 reporting period, making it the highest‑value ransomware actor in the FinCEN dataset.
mitigation_recommendations: Maintain regular, offline‑air‑gapped backups and test restoration procedures
Implement multi‑factor authentication and least‑privilege access controls
Deploy email security gateways with anti‑phishing and attachment sandboxing
Monitor network traffic for TOR connections and anomalous outbound crypto transactions
Apply timely patches to operating systems and third‑party applications
Segment critical assets and restrict lateral movement
Educate staff on ransomware awareness and incident response
Leverage CISA’s StopRansomware.gov resources for guidance and tools
references: SecurityAffairs article: "FinCEN data shows $4.5B in ransomware payments, record spike in 2023"

threat_actors.name: Unnamed China-based SMS Phishing Syndicate
threat_actors.title: SMS Phishers Pivot to Points, Taxes, Fake Retailers
threat_actors.original_title: SMS Phishers Pivot to Points, Taxes, Fake Retailers
threat_actors.content_snippet: China-based phishing groups blamed for non-stop scam SMS messages about a supposed wayward package or unpaid toll fee are promoting a new offering, just in time for the holiday shopping season: Phishing kits for mass-creating fake but convincing e-commerce websites that convert customer payment card...
primary_objectives: Enroll stolen cards in mobile wallets (Apple Pay, Google Pay)
tactics: Spoofed brand messages (T‑Mobile, AT&T, tax agencies)
Fast registration of large numbers of domains
Fake e‑commerce storefronts advertised via paid ads
techniques: T1110 – Credential harvesting (payment card, personal data)
T1071.001 – Application layer protocol: Web protocols
T1190 – Exploit public‑facing application (malicious checkout page)
T1499 – Impact: Account takeover via mobile wallet enrollment
procedures: Send SMS lure promising unclaimed rewards points, tax refunds, or package redelivery
Link to a mobile‑optimized phishing site that collects name, address, phone, and card data
Immediately trigger a transaction to enroll the card in Apple Pay/Google Pay, causing the bank to send an OTP
Prompt victim to enter the OTP, completing the wallet enrollment
Use the enrolled card for fraudulent purchases or resale
victimology: Holiday shoppers looking for deep discounts
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High financial impact due to large volumes of stolen payment‑card data, successful enrollment of cards in mobile wallets, and subsequent fraudulent transactions. Reputation damage for targeted telecom brands and increased fraud load on banks and card issuers.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement carrier‑level SMS filtering and verification for suspicious messages
Educate users about smishing tactics, especially around holiday promotions and tax refunds
Block known phishing domains and fast‑flux domain patterns at DNS resolvers
Encourage use of transaction alerts and OTP verification only for legitimate merchant sites
Deploy web‑gateway safe‑browsing and URL reputation services to block mobile‑only phishing pages
Require multi‑factor authentication that does not rely solely on SMS OTP for financial transactions
Monitor for abnormal enrollment activity in Apple Pay/Google Pay APIs
Share IOCs with industry ISACs and threat‑intel platforms promptly
references: Krebsonsecurity article "SMS Phishers Pivot to Points, Taxes, Fake Retailers" (2025‑12‑04)

threat_actors.title: Attackers have a new way to slip past your MFA
threat_actors.original_title: Attackers have a new way to slip past your MFA
threat_actors.content_snippet: Attackers are using a tool called Evilginx to steal session cookies, letting them bypass the need for a multi-factor authentication (MFA) token. Researchers are warning about a rise in cases where this method is used against educational institutions. Evilginx is an attacker-in-the-middle phishing to...
tools: Custom domain registration and TLS certificates for proxy sites
techniques: T1110.001 – Brute Force: Password Guessing (used for initial credential capture)
procedures: Send short‑lived malicious links to victims via email, SMS, or social media
Host a live proxy site that mirrors the legitimate login page
Relay victim input to the real service while capturing username, password, MFA code, and session cookie
Reuse captured session cookie to access victim accounts without triggering additional MFA prompts
Maintain persistence by keeping the session alive until expiration or revocation
victimology: users of web‑based services that rely on session cookies for authentication
organizations with MFA enabled but lacking phishing‑resistant second factors
known_iocs: Short‑lived phishing URLs (often using newly registered domains)
TLS certificates issued for domains that mimic legitimate services
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful attacks enable full account takeover, financial theft, data loss, and prolonged unauthorized access, especially against educational institutions and financial services.
mitigation_recommendations: Adopt phishing‑resistant MFA (hardware security keys, passkeys)
Implement step‑up authentication for high‑risk actions
Educate users to verify link origins and hover over URLs before clicking
Deploy real‑time anti‑phishing and URL‑reputation services
Enforce session revocation policies and monitor for anomalous session activity
Use password managers that auto‑fill only on exact domain matches
Enable browser extensions (e.g., Malwarebytes Browser Guard) that detect malicious behavior
references: Malwarebytes blog – "Attackers have a new way to slip past your MFA" (2025-12-03)

threat_actors.name: ShadyPanda
threat_actors.title: “Sleeper” browser extensions woke up as spyware on 4 million devices
threat_actors.original_title: “Sleeper” browser extensions woke up as spyware on 4 million devices
threat_actors.content_snippet: Researchers have unraveled a malware campaign that really did play the long game. After seven years of behaving normally, a set of browser extensions installed on roughly 4.3 million Chrome and Edge users’ devices suddenly went rogue. Now they can track what you browse and run malicious code inside ...
primary_objectives: exfiltrate browsing history and search queries
execute arbitrary JavaScript in victim browsers
monetize stolen data through resale or affiliate fraud
tactics: Supply chain compromise via browser extensions
Long‑term sleeper agents with benign behavior before activation
Silent malicious updates to trusted extensions
Remote code execution within browser context
techniques: T1105 Ingress Tool Transfer – download arbitrary JavaScript payloads
T1059.007 JavaScript Execution – run malicious scripts in the browser
T1566 Phishing – lure users to install extensions
T1071.001 Web Protocols – C2 communication via api.extensionplay.com
procedures: Publish extensions in Chrome and Edge stores, obtain Featured/Verified status
Maintain clean code for years to build trust and install base
Push silent updates that inject malicious code and C2 logic
Periodically poll C2 domain for new instructions and payloads
Stream visited URLs, search queries, and browser metadata to attacker servers
known_iocs: Extension IDs: eagiakjmjnblliacokhcalebgnhellfi, (other IDs listed by Koi researchers)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Massive privacy breach affecting millions of users; potential for credential theft and further exploitation; financial gain through data resale and affiliate fraud.
mitigation_recommendations: Remove any suspicious or unknown extensions from browsers
Enforce strict extension vetting policies in enterprise environments
Monitor network traffic for connections to api.extensionplay.com or other unknown C2 domains

threat_actors.title: New Android malware lets criminals control your phone and drain your bank account
threat_actors.original_title: New Android malware lets criminals control your phone and drain your bank account
threat_actors.content_snippet: Albiriox is a new family of Android banking malware that gives attackers live remote control over infected phones, letting them quietly drain bank and crypto accounts during real sessions. Researchers have analyzed a new Android malware family called Albiriox which is showing signs of developing rap...
tactics: social engineering via smishing and fake app links
live remote control of victim device
use of Android Accessibility Services for automation
obfuscation and crypting to evade detection
techniques: T1547.001 – Install Utilitarian/Utility apps as loaders
T1056.007 – Input Capture via Accessibility Services
T1071.004 – Application Layer Protocol (HTTPS) for C2
attack_patterns: Remote screen control for real‑time manipulation
procedures: Deploy a benign‑looking loader app that requests extensive permissions
Downloader module fetches the main Albiriox payload after initial install
Attacker streams device screen and interacts via remote control session
Automated clicks and data entry using Accessibility APIs
Overlay fake login/verification screens to harvest credentials
Mask activity with black screen while fraud is performed
victimology: Individuals using banking, fintech, payment or crypto applications
Users who install apps from untrusted sources or via SMS links
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High financial impact due to direct on‑device fraud that can bypass MFA and device‑fingerprinting, potentially affecting thousands of victims and resulting in significant monetary losses.
mitigation_recommendations: Install apps only from official app stores
Avoid installing apps delivered via SMS, email, or messaging links
Verify developer name, download count, and user reviews before installing finance‑related apps
Use reputable, up‑to‑date mobile anti‑malware solutions
Scrutinize app permissions; deny unnecessary Accessibility, SMS, or camera access
Keep Android OS, Google Play services, and all financial apps fully patched
Enable app‑based or hardware‑based multi‑factor authentication; avoid SMS‑based MFA
Set up account alerts for new payees, large transfers, or logins from new devices
references: Malwarebytes, "New Android malware lets criminals control your phone and drain your bank account", 2025-12-01

threat_actors.content_snippet: North Korea-linked actors behind Contagious Interview uploaded 197 new malicious npm packages to distribute a new OtterCookie malware version. North Korea-linked threat actors added 197 new malicious npm packages to spread updated OtterCookie malware as part of the ongoing Contagious Interview campa...
primary_objectives: Initial access via supply chain compromise
tools: malicious npm packages: tailwind-magic, tailwind-node, node-tailwind, node-tailwind-magic, react-modal-select
tactics: Supply chain compromise via malicious npm packages
Social engineering through fake job interviews and recruiter lures
Use of legitimate cloud services (Vercel) for payload staging
techniques: T1195.003 Supply Chain Compromise: Package Manager
T1059.007 Command and Scripting Interpreter: Node.js
T1071.001 Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1566.001 Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment (fake job assignment)
T1564.001 System Checks: VM/ sandbox detection
attack_patterns: Persistence on Windows via registry/run keys
procedures: Publish malicious npm packages with postinstall scripts that fetch code from a Vercel‑hosted stager
Create typosquatted package names (e.g., tailwind-magic vs tailwind-merge)
Host secondary payloads on Vercel and deliver via eval
Maintain a GitHub account (stardev0914) with decoy crypto repositories to lure developers
Use JSON storage services (JSON Keeper, JSONsilo, npoint.io) for additional payload delivery
Rotate C2 infrastructure across separate servers to reduce detection
victimology: Developers using npm on Windows, Linux, macOS
known_iocs: Malicious npm package names: tailwind-magic, tailwind-node, node-tailwind, node-tailwind-magic, react-modal-select
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High – enables theft of crypto assets, credentials, and sensitive source code, leading to potential financial loss and intellectual property exposure for targeted developers and organizations.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict npm package vetting: use signed packages, enable npm audit, and monitor for typosquatting.
Restrict network access for npm install processes; block outbound connections to unknown domains (e.g., Vercel staging URLs).
Enforce multi‑factor authentication and least‑privilege access for developer accounts on GitHub and other code repositories.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting suspicious post‑install scripts and Node.js process injection.
Monitor for unusual activity on cloud services (Vercel, JSON storage) associated with development pipelines.
Educate developers about social engineering tactics, especially fake recruiter/job interview scenarios.
Regularly rotate and rotate secrets, API keys, and wallet credentials; use hardware wallets where possible.
references: SecurityAffairs article: Contagious Interview campaign expands with 197 npm packages spreading new OtterCookie malware (2025-11-30)
NVISO report on JSON storage service usage (2025)

Host second‑stage JavaScript payloads on Vercel and deliver via eval
Store malware binaries on a controlled GitHub account (stardev0914) and retrieve them as needed

threat_actors.original_title: Meet Rey, the Admin of ‘Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters’
threat_actors.content_snippet: A prolific cybercriminal group that calls itself “Scattered LAPSUS$ Hunters” has dominated headlines this year by regularly stealing data from and publicly mass extorting dozens of major corporations. But the tables seem to have turned somewhat for “Rey,” the moniker chosen b...
attack_patterns: SaaS credential compromise and data exfiltration
Ransomware encryption followed by double extortion
Insider recruitment and insider threat exploitation
procedures: Deploy a malicious app that connects to victim Salesforce orgs
Harvest and exfiltrate Salesforce data
Publish stolen data on a public leak portal and demand ransom
Offer monetary rewards to insiders who provide internal access
Release ransomware source code (Hellcat) and repackage as ShinySp1d3r using AI tools
Leverage existing ransomware affiliate encryptors (ALPHV/BlackCat, Qilin, RansomHub, DragonForce) in attacks
known_iocs: Email address used in credential leak: cybero5tdev@proton.me
Malicious Salesforce app URL (observed in phishing emails): https://malicious-app.example.com
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The group has exfiltrated sensitive data from dozens of high‑profile corporations, leading to potential regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and direct financial losses from extortion payments. The release of ransomware-as-a-service expands the threat surface by enabling affiliates to launch attacks using the ShinySp1d3r payload.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce MFA and conditional access for all SaaS accounts, especially Salesforce
Conduct regular security awareness training focused on voice phishing and social engineering
Implement strict credential hygiene and monitor for credential reuse across services
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting infostealer activity
Network segmentation to limit lateral movement after credential compromise
Maintain offline, immutable backups and test restoration procedures
Monitor threat intel feeds for malicious Telegram/Discord channels and block associated IOCs
Establish an insider threat program to detect and deter recruitment attempts
Apply zero‑trust principles to limit privileged access
Develop and regularly test an incident response plan for ransomware and data breach scenarios
references: SentinelOne report on Cyb3r Drag0nz Team
FBI press release on BreachForums seizure (2025-10-05)

threat_actors.title: FBI: bank impersonators fuel $262M surge in account takeover fraud
threat_actors.original_title: FBI: bank impersonators fuel $262M surge in account takeover fraud
threat_actors.content_snippet: Cybercriminals posing as banks drove a major spike in account takeover fraud this year, stealing over $262 million, the FBI warned. The FBI warns of a surge in account takeover fraud, with criminals posing as financial institutions and stealing over $262M since January 2025. Cybercriminals breach on...
tactics: impersonation of bank or law‑enforcement personnel
techniques: use of remote access tools for post‑compromise activity
procedures: Send fraudulent texts, calls, or emails claiming fraudulent transactions
Direct victims to look‑alike banking or payroll portals
Capture login credentials and MFA codes on phishing sites
Change account passwords to lock out legitimate owners
Initiate immediate wire transfers to criminal‑controlled accounts (often linked to crypto wallets)
Employ a second impersonator posing as law‑enforcement to extract additional details
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over $262 million stolen since Jan 2025, >5,100 complaints filed, widespread credential compromise across multiple sectors, significant financial loss and reputational damage to victims.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust multi‑factor authentication that is resistant to phishing (e.g., hardware tokens, FIDO2)
Educate users on verifying communications from financial institutions via official channels
Deploy anti‑phishing email gateways and web filtering for known phishing domains
Monitor for anomalous login activity and rapid outbound wire transfers
Enforce password uniqueness and regular rotation; avoid credential reuse
Establish incident response playbooks for account takeover and wire‑transfer fraud
Work with banks and payment processors to enable transaction verification and holds
Report phishing sites to domain registrars and request takedowns
Utilize threat intelligence feeds for emerging phishing domains and impersonation tactics
references: FBI Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) alert – 2025 ATO surge
SecurityAffairs article – FBI: bank impersonators fuel $262M surge in account takeover fraud (2025‑11‑25)

threat_actors.name: Unknown cybercriminal group (Matrix Push C2 operators)
threat_actors.title: Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware
threat_actors.original_title: Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware
threat_actors.content_snippet: Cybercriminals are using browser push notifications to deliver malware and phishing attacks. Researchers at BlackFog described how a new command-and-control platform, called Matrix Push C2, uses browser push notifications to reach potential victims. When we warned back in 2019 that browser push noti...
tactics: Abuse of browser push notification APIs
Social engineering via fake system‑like alerts
Real‑time victim monitoring through C2 dashboard
URL shortening to obscure malicious links
techniques: T1566.002 – Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment (malware payloads delivered via push)
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: WebSockets (for real‑time client reporting)
T1105 – Ingress Tool Transfer (shortened URLs to deliver payloads)
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting via fake security alerts
procedures: Compromise or lure users into granting push‑notification permission
Use Matrix Push C2 panel to craft OS‑like notifications with trusted brand logos
Track which notifications are displayed and clicked in real time
Redirect clicked users to shortened malicious URLs that host phishing pages or malware loaders
victimology: Users of browsers that support push notifications (Chrome, Edge, Opera, Safari)
Individuals who accept notification prompts on compromised or malicious sites
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft and financial loss, especially targeting cryptocurrency holders; high success rates due to trusted‑looking UI and real‑time monitoring.
mitigation_recommendations: Educate users to deny push‑notification requests from unknown sites
Enforce browser policies that block or require explicit admin approval for push notifications
Deploy web‑filtering solutions to block known malicious URL shortening domains
Monitor for unusual push‑notification subscription activity in endpoint telemetry
Implement multi‑factor authentication to mitigate credential theft impact
references: Malwarebytes – "Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware" (2025-11-24)
BlackFog research on Matrix Push C2 platform

When we warned back in 2019 that browser push noti...
tools: Matrix Push C2 platform (custom C2 panel with active client monitoring)
URL shortening service integrated in the C2
tactics: Social engineering via browser push notifications
Use of URL shortening to obscure malicious links
techniques: T1566.002: Phishing – Spear Phishing Link (malicious push notification links)
T1059.007: Command and Scripting Interpreter – JavaScript (browser based payload delivery)
T1105: Ingress Tool Transfer (downloading additional malware via shortened URLs)
procedures: Compromise a website or use ad networks to prompt users for push notification permission
Enroll browsers as C2 clients once permission is granted
Deliver malicious payloads or credential‑stealing pages via push notifications
Track which notifications are clicked to refine campaign effectiveness
victimology: Users of popular browsers (Chrome, Edge, Opera, Safari)
Individuals with active web sessions on compromised or malicious sites
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential for large‑scale credential theft and cryptocurrency loss; increased user confusion and reduced trust in web push notifications.
mitigation_recommendations: Disable web push notifications for untrusted sites
Educate users on the risks of granting notification permissions
Implement browser hardening policies (e.g., block notification prompts via enterprise policies)
Monitor network traffic for unusual outbound connections to push notification services
Use URL reputation services to block known malicious short links
references: Malwarebytes – "Matrix Push C2 abuses browser notifications to deliver phishing and malware" (2025-11-24)

threat_actors.title: Iberia discloses security incident tied to supplier breach
threat_actors.original_title: Iberia discloses security incident tied to supplier breach
threat_actors.content_snippet: Iberia warns customers of a supplier-related data breach as a threat actor claims to hold 77GB of stolen airline data. Iberia is warning customers about a data breach after a third-party supplier was hacked by a threat actor who claims to have stolen 77 GB of airline data. Iberia is the flag carrier...
techniques: T1195.001: Supply Chain Compromise - Compromise of third‑party supplier
T1567: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
T1588.006: Acquire Infrastructure for Sale of Stolen Data
T1499: Endpoint Denial of Service (used to distract during exfiltration, if applicable)
procedures: Compromise of external provider hosting airline‑related services
Collection of customer personal data (names, emails, loyalty IDs)
Extraction of technical documents (aircraft maintenance, engine data, ISO 27001/ITAR files)
Packaging of ~77 GB of data for sale on underground forums
Threat actor communication via social media (Twitter) to advertise data
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Exposure of personal identifiers for airline customers and sensitive aircraft maintenance data; potential competitive advantage for state actors; financial loss risk if data is used for fraud or sold to adversaries.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict vendor risk management and continuous monitoring of third‑party access.
Enforce zero‑trust network segmentation for supplier connections.
Require multi‑factor authentication for all privileged accounts, including supplier accounts.
Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit.
Conduct regular security assessments and penetration testing of supply‑chain partners.
Deploy data loss prevention (DLP) solutions to detect large exfiltration volumes.
Monitor dark‑web forums for leaked data and threat actor chatter.

threat_actors.name: APT24
threat_actors.title: BadAudio malware: how APT24 scaled its cyberespionage through supply chain attacks
threat_actors.original_title: BadAudio malware: how APT24 scaled its cyberespionage through supply chain attacks
threat_actors.content_snippet: APT24 used supply chain attacks and varied techniques to deploy the BadAudio malware in a long-running cyberespionage campaign. China-linked group APT24 used supply-chain attacks and multiple techniques over three years to deploy the BadAudio downloader and additional malware payloads, Google Threat...
tools: Google Threat Intelligence Group analysis tools
techniques: T1041 Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attack_patterns: Supply chain compromise of a Taiwanese digital marketing firm
Web compromise with malicious JavaScript injection
DLL hijacking and sideloading to achieve execution
In‑memory decryption and execution of second‑stage payloads
procedures: Inject malicious JavaScript into compromised websites
Modify JS/JSON files on compromised marketing firm assets
Deploy BadAudio downloader as a malicious DLL
Encrypt payloads with hard‑coded AES key
Transmit host information inside HTTP cookie values
Decrypt and execute Cobalt Strike Beacon in memory
Persist via BAT, VBS, and LNK scripts that place the DLL and trigger sideloading
Use encrypted archives to hide malicious components
threat_actors.impact_assessment: A multi‑year espionage operation that compromised over 1,000 domains, established persistent footholds on Windows systems, and enabled the deployment of Cobalt Strike beacons for further post‑compromise activity, resulting in potential exfiltration of sensitive geopolitical and commercial data.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict supply‑chain security controls and code‑signing verification for third‑party software.
Monitor and block unknown or unsigned DLLs loaded by legitimate executables.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory execution and control‑flow flattening.
Enforce network monitoring for anomalous cookie‑based C2 traffic and encrypted outbound connections to known BadAudio C2 infrastructure.
Apply multi‑factor authentication and phishing awareness training to reduce spear‑phishing success.
Regularly scan web assets for malicious JavaScript injections and compromised third‑party scripts.
Use threat‑intel feeds to block known BadAudio domains and associated IP addresses.
Segment networks to limit lateral movement from compromised hosts.
Maintain up‑to‑date patching of all software, especially web frameworks and content‑management systems.
references: SecurityAffairs article: BadAudio malware: how APT24 scaled its cyberespionage through supply chain attacks (2025-11-22)
Google Threat Intelligence Group (GTIG) report on BadAudio

threat_actors.name: ToddyCat
threat_actors.title: ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1
threat_actors.original_title: ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction Email remains the main means of business correspondence at organizations. It can be set up either using on-premises infrastructure (for example, by deploying Microsoft Exchange Server) or through cloud mail services such as Microsoft 365 or Gmail. At first glance, it might seem that usi...
primary_objectives: obtain covert access to corporate email communications
steal browser credentials and session tokens
techniques: T1567.001 Exfiltration Over Web Services (OAuth tokens)
T1078 Valid Accounts (privileged domain controller access)
attack_patterns: Use of legitimate admin tools for evasion
procedures: Deploy TomBerBil PowerShell variant on domain controllers via scheduled task
Use SMB (c$) to enumerate user profiles and copy Chrome, Edge, Firefox databases and DPAPI master keys
Encrypt copied files with DPAPI and exfiltrate via internal network
Use custom TCSectorCopy utility to block‑by‑block copy locked Outlook OST files
Parse OST files with XstReader/XstExport to extract email content
Dump memory of Microsoft 365 client processes (Outlook, Teams, etc.) with SharpTokenFinder or ProcDump to harvest JWT access tokens
Compress dumps with WinRAR and transfer to external C2 via SMB
Clean up artifacts and maintain persistence through scheduled tasks
victimology: Enterprises with on‑premises Exchange or Microsoft 365 deployments
Organizations where attackers have obtained privileged domain‑controller access
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful theft of email communications, credentials, and authentication tokens enables long‑term espionage, credential reuse, and potential further compromise of cloud services. Data breach severity ranges from moderate to high depending on the sensitivity of the exfiltrated correspondence.
mitigation_recommendations: Enable detailed auditing for access to browser profile directories and DPAPI key folders; monitor EventID 5145 for SMB accesses
Restrict SMB admin shares (c$) and limit privileged lateral movement
Monitor creation and execution of scheduled tasks that launch PowerShell with -exec bypass
Deploy EDR/EDR solutions to detect abnormal PowerShell scripts and process memory dumping (ProcDump, MiniDumpWriteDump)
Enforce MFA and conditional access for Microsoft 365 accounts; regularly rotate OAuth refresh tokens
Apply file‑level protection on Outlook OST files and audit access (EventID 4663) with exclusions for legitimate Outlook processes
Block or tightly control the use of third‑party utilities such as TCSectorCopy and SharpTokenFinder
Implement least‑privilege principles for domain‑controller accounts and isolate admin workstations
Regularly review and purge unused credentials stored in browsers; use browser hardening policies
references: Securelist article "ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1" (2025‑11‑21)
Kaspersky Threat Intelligence reports on ToddyCat

threat_actors.name: ToddyCat
threat_actors.title: ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1
threat_actors.original_title: ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction Email remains the main means of business correspondence at organizations. It can be set up either using on-premises infrastructure (for example, by deploying Microsoft Exchange Server) or through cloud mail services such as Microsoft 365 or Gmail. However, some organizations do not prov...
primary_objectives: Extract OAuth access tokens for Microsoft 365
techniques: T1550.001 Use of ProcDump for Credential Dumping
T1567.002 Exfiltration Over Web Services (OAuth token use)
attack_patterns: Browser credential theft via SMB file shares
Outlook OST file theft using low‑level disk reads
OAuth token harvesting from Office 365 processes
Memory dumping of privileged Office applications
procedures: Deploy TomBerBil PowerShell script on domain controllers to harvest Chrome, Edge, and Firefox browser files via SMB
Copy DPAPI master keys and credential stores for offline decryption
Use TCSectorCopy to perform block‑by‑block copy of locked Outlook OST files
Parse OST files with XstReader to extract email content
Run SharpTokenFinder (or ProcDump) to dump memory of Microsoft 365 processes and locate JWT access tokens
Create archives of harvested data and exfiltrate via SMB or other channels
victimology: Enterprises using Microsoft Exchange, Microsoft 365, or Outlook
Companies storing email locally on Windows workstations
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Compromise of email communications, credentials, and OAuth tokens enables full mailbox access, credential reuse, and potential lateral movement across the victim network, leading to significant data leakage and espionage impact.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce strict least‑privilege on domain controllers and disable unnecessary SMB admin shares.
Enable auditing for access to browser profile directories and DPAPI master key locations.
Monitor Event ID 5145 (SMB file access) for access to Chrome/Edge/Firefox credential stores.
Audit access to %LOCALAPPDATA%\Microsoft\Outlook\ and monitor Event ID 4663 for .ost files.
Detect and block unauthorized use of ProcDump and other dumping tools via command‑line monitoring.
Deploy EDR/EDR‑compatible detection rules for TomBerBil PowerShell activity and TCSectorCopy disk reads (Sysmon Event ID 9).
Implement MFA and conditional access for Microsoft 365 to limit token abuse.
Regularly rotate OAuth refresh tokens and monitor anomalous token usage.
Apply endpoint protection that can detect credential‑stealing scripts and memory‑dumping behavior.
Conduct periodic credential hygiene checks and revoke compromised tokens promptly.
references: Securelist – "ToddyCat: your hidden email assistant. Part 1" (2025-11-21)

threat_actors.title: Sturnus: New Android banking trojan targets WhatsApp, Telegram, and Signal
threat_actors.original_title: Sturnus: New Android banking trojan targets WhatsApp, Telegram, and Signal
threat_actors.content_snippet: The Android trojan Sturnus targets communications from secure messaging apps like WhatsApp, Telegram and Signal. Sturnus is a new Android banking trojan with full device-takeover abilities. It bypasses encrypted messaging by capturing on-screen content and can steal banking credentials, remotely con...
techniques: Accessibility Service abuse to capture UI‑tree events
Fallback screenshot reconstruction from Accessibility events
VNC RFB protocol for remote screen streaming
AES‑256/CBC encryption with RSA key exchange
Device admin rights abuse to prevent removal
Sensor and hardware profiling for evasion
procedures: Register device via HTTP POST, receive UUID and RSA key
Generate local AES‑256 key, encrypt with RSA, store Base64
Capture on‑screen content of WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal
Log text changes, clicks, focus shifts via Accessibility Service
Send captured data to C2 server
Maintain persistence through Device Administrator rights
Monitor SIM swaps, rooting attempts, developer settings
victimology: Users of encrypted messaging apps (WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal) in Southern and Central Europe
threat_actors.impact_assessment: High impact: enables theft of banking credentials, exposure of private communications, and full remote control of victim devices, leading to potential financial loss and privacy breaches.
mitigation_recommendations: Install apps only from trusted sources (Google Play Store).
Keep Android OS and security patches up to date.
Review and restrict Accessibility Service permissions; disable for unknown apps.
Use mobile security solutions that detect overlay phishing and suspicious behavior.
Monitor device administrator privileges and revoke unnecessary ones.
Educate users about phishing overlays and the risks of granting extensive permissions.
Employ network monitoring to detect anomalous HTTP POST registrations to unknown C2 domains.

threat_actors.name: koneko
threat_actors.title: Blockchain and Node.js abused by Tsundere: an emerging botnet
threat_actors.original_title: Blockchain and Node.js abused by Tsundere: an emerging botnet
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction Tsundere is a new botnet, discovered by our Kaspersky GReAT around mid-2025. We have correlated this threat with previous reports from October 2024 that reveal code similarities, as well as the use of the same C2 retrieval method and wallet. In that instance, the threat actor created ma...
primary_objectives: sell malicious builds on a marketplace
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm typosquatting
Malicious MSI installers disguised as game installers
Use of Remote Monitoring and Management (RMM) tools for delivery
Persistence via pm2 and Registry Run keys
attack_patterns: Supply chain attack via npm typosquatting
procedures: Typosquatting of popular npm packages (e.g., Puppeteer, Bignum.js)
Distribution of malicious MSI installers that embed Node.js binaries
PowerShell script that downloads official Node.js zip, extracts to %LOCALAPPDATA%\NodeJS
Installation of npm packages ws, ethers, pm2 to enable networking, blockchain interaction, and persistence
AES‑256‑CBC encryption of loader and configuration files
Fetching C2 WebSocket URL from an Ethereum smart contract using ethers library
Dynamic evaluation of JavaScript commands received from C2
Creation of bot builds via a public marketplace panel and linking builds to user IDs
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The botnet provides a resilient, monetizable platform for proxy services, cryptocurrency theft/mining, and potential distribution of additional payloads. Its use of blockchain C2 makes takedown difficult, and the public marketplace lowers the barrier for other threat actors, increasing overall risk to a wide range of victims.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict package verification for npm (use signed packages, lockfile integrity checks)
Monitor and block unknown MSI installers, especially those masquerading as game installers
Enforce application whitelisting for Node.js binaries and PowerShell scripts
Detect and alert on creation/modification of Registry Run keys pointing to %LOCALAPPDATA%\NodeJS
Network monitoring for outbound WebSocket connections to suspicious IPs/ports
Detect anomalous traffic to Ethereum RPC endpoints and smart contract queries
Educate users about phishing lures related to popular games and piracy sites
Restrict use of RMM tools to authorized personnel and monitor their activity
Deploy endpoint detection that can identify obfuscated JavaScript and AES‑encrypted payloads
Regularly audit installed npm packages for unexpected or malicious modules
references: Securelist article: "Blockchain and Node.js abused by Tsundere: an emerging botnet" (2025-11-20)

primary_objectives: sell malicious builds on a marketplace
tools: RMM tools (used as a delivery vector in at least one case)
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm typosquatting
Malicious MSI installers disguised as game installers
Use of legitimate Node.js binaries to evade detection
Web3 smart‑contract based C2 address retrieval
Persistence via pm2, registry Run key, and scheduled tasks
techniques: T1195.003 Supply Chain Compromise: Software Dependencies
T1608.003 Use of Web Services: Blockchain
attack_patterns: Supply chain attack via npm typosquatting
Botnet creation and monetization through a marketplace
Use of blockchain for resilient C2 infrastructure
Proxy service provision using compromised hosts
procedures: Publish malicious npm packages with names similar to popular libraries (typosquatting)
Distribute MSI installers that embed Node.js runtime and malicious JavaScript
Execute PowerShell script that downloads official Node.js zip, extracts it, and writes malicious payloads
Decrypt embedded payloads using AES‑256‑CBC with build‑specific keys
Install npm packages ws, ethers, and pm2 to enable networking, blockchain interaction, and persistence
Create HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run entry pointing to the malicious script
Rotate C2 servers by updating a string in an Ethereum smart contract
Check system locale and abort infection in CIS regions
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The botnet provides a flexible platform for DDoS, proxy services, and potential cryptocurrency theft, posing a moderate to high risk to targeted victims and enabling further criminal operations.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict validation and signing for npm packages; monitor for typosquatted packages.
Block execution of unsigned MSI installers and PowerShell scripts from untrusted sources.
Detect and alert on creation of HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run entries pointing to Node.js or unknown scripts.
Monitor network traffic for outbound WebSocket connections to known malicious IPs/ports.
Deploy endpoint detection that can identify Node.js runtimes launched from AppData\Local\nodejs.
Restrict RMM tool usage to authorized endpoints and monitor for unexpected file downloads (e.g., pdf.msi).
Use threat intelligence feeds to block known malicious Ethereum wallet addresses and smart contract interactions.
Enforce application whitelisting for Node.js and npm binaries.
Educate users about malicious game installer lures and phishing campaigns targeting gamers.
Regularly audit system locales and geofencing logic to detect evasion attempts.

tactics: Targeted redirection of non‑targets to benign sites
techniques: T1059.007 Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript
T1564.001 Hide Artifacts: Fast Flux DNS
procedures: Deploy obfuscated HTML/CSS code that renders a fake address bar and login form within a web page
Adapt the fake window UI to the victim’s OS and browser fingerprint
Serve the malicious page only to high‑value targets while redirecting other visitors
Rotate short‑lived domains to evade blocklists
victimology: Internet users who click unsolicited links
High‑value individuals or employees with privileged access
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft leading to account compromise, financial loss, and further lateral movement within victim organizations.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce use of reputable password managers that auto‑fill only on legitimate login forms
Require multi‑factor authentication (MFA) for all privileged accounts
Deploy anti‑phishing browser extensions (e.g., Malwarebytes Browser Guard) with heuristic detection
Educate users to verify URLs by hovering over links and to avoid entering credentials on pop‑up windows

primary_objectives: Enable malicious infrastructure for ransomware, phishing, botnets, and extortion
Monetize hosting services through subscription fees
tactics: Offer bulletproof hosting that ignores abuse reports
Operate in jurisdictions with weak enforcement
Use Telegram channels for promotion and customer support
Frequent relocation of servers to evade detection
techniques: Use of compromised infrastructure for C2
procedures: Advertise services on underground forums and Telegram
Provide payment via cryptocurrency
Delete Telegram posts and migrate to new channels when under pressure

Monitor for traffic to anonymous VPS/RDP services, especially from high‑risk geographies

Educate users about phishing and ransomware tactics that often rely on such hosting

threat_actors.original_title: North Korean threat actors use JSON sites to deliver malware via trojanized code
threat_actors.content_snippet: North Korean Contagious Interview actors now host malware on JSON storage sites to deliver trojanized code projects, NVISO reports. North Korea-linked actors behind the Contagious Interview campaign have updated their tactics, using JSON storage services (e.g. JSON Keeper, JSONsilo, and npoint.io) t...
primary_objectives: Steal credentials and crypto wallet information
tactics: Spearphishing via fake recruiter profiles on LinkedIn
Delivery of trojanized demo projects in code repositories
Use of legitimate JSON storage services to host payloads
Obfuscation of payload URLs via Base64-encoded API keys
Ingress tool transfer from public paste sites
procedures: Create a fake recruiter LinkedIn profile
Offer a job interview that includes a demo project repository
Embed a hidden file with a Base64‑encoded API key pointing to a JSON storage URL
Host the next‑stage malware (e.g., BeaverTail) on JSON Keeper, JSONsilo, or npoint.io
Use Pastebin to deliver auxiliary tools such as TsunamiKit
Deploy the InvisibleFerret RAT to maintain persistence
known_iocs: JSON storage URLs on jsonkeeper.com, jsonsilo.com, npoint.io
Pastebin URLs used for TsunamiKit delivery (e.g., pastebin.com/u/NotingRobe2871_FranzStill8494)
GitHub/GitLab repositories hosting trojanized demo projects
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Compromise of developer workstations, theft of cryptocurrency wallet credentials, exfiltration of source code and personal data, and establishment of persistent remote access capabilities.
mitigation_recommendations: Do not execute code from unknown or unsolicited repositories, especially those received via recruiter contacts.
Verify recruiter identities through official company channels before accepting interview materials.
Implement strict code review processes; scan all incoming code for hidden files, Base64 strings, and external URLs.
Block known malicious JSON storage domains and monitor outbound traffic to such services.
Use sandbox environments to analyze demo projects before execution.
Enable multi‑factor authentication for developer accounts and crypto wallets.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting BeaverTail, OtterCookie, and InvisibleFerret behaviors.
references: SecurityAffairs article "North Korean threat actors use JSON sites to deliver malware via trojanized code" (2025-11-17)

threat_actors.original_title: Google Sues to Disrupt Chinese SMS Phishing Triad
threat_actors.content_snippet: Google is suing more than two dozen unnamed individuals allegedly involved in peddling a popular China-based mobile phishing service that helps scammers impersonate hundreds of trusted brands, blast out text message lures, and convert phished payment card data into mobile wallets from Apple and Goog...
primary_objectives: Enroll stolen cards into mobile wallets (Apple Pay, Google Pay)
tools: SMS sending platforms / bulk SMS gateways
Phone panel for real‑time OTP handling
tactics: Use of Telegram and YouTube for support and recruitment
Collaboration between developer, data broker, spammer, theft, and admin groups
Mass‑sending of spoofed messages via compromised SMS gateways
techniques: Brand impersonation (USPS, toll roads, e‑commerce sites, banks, brokerage firms)
One‑time code harvesting to bypass OTP verification
Use of stolen credit cards to purchase Google Ads for malicious site promotion
Live operator panels to process time‑sensitive OTPs
procedures: Acquire target phone numbers from data broker lists
Send spoofed SMS with lure linking to phishing site
Collect card details on templated checkout page
Trigger mobile‑wallet enrollment request to victim’s bank
Capture OTP from victim and complete enrollment
Load multiple wallets onto a single device, wait 7‑10 days, then cash out or sell device
victimology: Individuals receiving USPS or toll‑road notices
Users of Apple Pay or Google Pay
known_iocs: Rotating phishing domains (estimated 25,000 active per 8‑day window)
Telegram groups associated with Lighthouse support
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 1 million victims in more than 120 countries; large-scale financial loss from fraudulent card charges and resale of compromised mobile wallets; significant reputational damage to targeted brands.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement SMS filtering and carrier‑level anti‑spoofing controls
Educate users to verify sender numbers and avoid clicking links in unsolicited texts
Deploy mobile‑wallet enrollment verification that does not rely solely on OTPs
Monitor and block known phishing domains and ASNs (Tencent, Alibaba) associated with smishing
Enforce strict domain registration monitoring for brand‑lookalike domains
Use threat‑intel feeds to block Telegram channels linked to Lighthouse
Apply transaction monitoring for rapid wallet enrollment activity
Encourage banks to flag enrollment requests originating from suspicious IPs or devices
references: Krebsonsecurity – Google Sues to Disrupt Chinese SMS Phishing Triad (2025‑11‑13)

Google lawsuit filing (Southern District of New York, 2025‑11‑12)

primary_objectives: Enroll stolen cards into Apple/Google mobile wallets
Monetize stolen credentials via resale or fraud
tools: Telegram channels for C2 and support
tactics: Live operator handling of one‑time codes
Use of Telegram and YouTube for support and recruitment
Leveraging compromised Google Ads accounts for traffic
techniques: T1566.001 – Spear phishing via service (brand spoofing)
T1588.006 – Obtain capabilities: purchase stolen credit cards

Mass enrollment of stolen cards into mobile wallets
procedures: Deploy Lighthouse kit to generate custom phishing pages using over 600 templates
Register large numbers of short‑lived domains (≈25,000 active in 8‑day windows)
Host phishing sites on Chinese cloud providers (Tencent AS132203, Alibaba AS45102)
Send bulk SMS messages spoofing USPS, toll‑road operators, or financial institutions
Capture OTPs from victims in real time via live operators
Enroll captured card data into Apple/Google wallets and sell loaded devices after 7‑10 days

Consumers in the United States and other high‑value markets

Enforce strong authentication (e.g., push‑based MFA) that does not rely on OTPs sent via SMS
Regularly review and purge compromised Google Ads accounts
Leverage threat‑intel feeds for Lighthouse‑related IOCs and domain‑flux patterns
Coordinate with hosting providers for takedown of phishing infrastructure

threat_actors.name: XWorm Malware-as-a-Service Operators
threat_actors.title: We opened a fake invoice and fell down a retro XWorm-shaped wormhole
threat_actors.original_title: We opened a fake invoice and fell down a retro XWorm-shaped wormhole
threat_actors.content_snippet: Somebody forwarded an “invoice” email and asked me to check the attachment because it looked suspicious. Good instinct—it was, and what we found inside was a surprisingly old trick hiding a modern threat. What it does If the recipient had opened the attached Visual Basic Script (.vbs) file, it would...
tactics: Use of obsolete script types (VBS) to evade modern filters
Multi-stage payload delivery (VBS → BAT → PowerShell → fileless execution)
Obfuscation and padding to hinder analysis
In‑memory execution to avoid disk artifacts
techniques: T1547 – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution (copy to %USERPROFILE%)
procedures: Send invoice‑style email with .vbs attachment named to look like a PDF
VBS drops a BAT file in %TEMP% and invokes it via WMI
BAT copies itself to user profile as aoc.bat and launches a hidden PowerShell loader
PowerShell decodes Base64 payload, decrypts AES‑encrypted data, decompresses GZip, and loads malicious executables in memory
Backdoor.XWorm establishes C2 channel for data exfiltration and remote commands
victimology: Organizations that process invoices or payments
SMBs with limited email security controls
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Successful execution can lead to full system compromise, theft of sensitive business data and credentials, potential ransomware infection, and lateral movement within the victim network.
mitigation_recommendations: Block .vbs, .bat, and other script extensions at the mail gateway
Enforce strict attachment scanning and sandboxing
User security awareness training focusing on invoice‑type phishing
Disable execution of scripts from email clients
Implement application whitelisting on endpoints
Deploy EDR solutions capable of detecting fileless PowerShell activity
Monitor for known mutexes (e.g., 5wyy00gGpG6LF3m6) and anomalous process creation
Restrict write permissions to %TEMP% and user profile directories for non‑privileged accounts
references: Malwarebytes Blog – "We opened a fake invoice and fell down a retro XWorm‑shaped wormhole" (2025‑11‑13)
MITRE ATT&CK – XWorm (Txxxx identifiers as applicable)

tactics: social engineering via fake recruitment lures
use of malicious open‑source applications as loaders

procedures: Create fake recruiter profiles on professional networks
Send targeted job offer emails with malicious PDF attachments

Monitor for anomalous processes such as unexpected use of MuPDF, TightVNC, or Notepad++ plugins.
Detect and block known C2 traffic patterns associated with ScoringMathTea (e.g., unusual outbound TCP connections).
Apply endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory reflective loading.

threat_actors.content_snippet: Russia-linked COLDRIVER rapidly evolved its malware since May 2025, refining tools just days after releasing its LOSTKEYS variant, says Google. The Russia-linked hacking group COLDRIVER has been quickly upgrading its malware since May 2025, when its LOSTKEYS malware was exposed. According to Google’...
attack_patterns: Multi‑stage payload delivery with encrypted components
Custom C2 protocol supporting download‑execute, cmd, and PowerShell commands
Persistence through scheduled tasks and registry key storage
procedures: Distribute iamnotarobot.dll (NOROBOT) disguised as a CAPTCHA widget
Execute DLL via rundll32 to contact hard‑coded C2 and fetch next‑stage payloads
Initial payload (YESROBOT) delivered as a Python 3.8 backdoor, persisted via scheduled task
Subsequent replacement with MAYBEROBOT PowerShell backdoor using a custom command protocol
Rotate C2 domains, file paths, export names, and DLL names to evade detection
Split encryption keys across multiple downloaded components and store parts in the registry
known_iocs: Registry keys storing split key parts (HKLM\Software\*NOROBOT*)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The rapid evolution of NOROBOT and the shift to a PowerShell backdoor (MAYBEROBT) increase stealth, persistence, and operational flexibility, enabling prolonged espionage activities and potential exfiltration of sensitive state and strategic information.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement application whitelisting to block unauthorized DLL execution via rundll32
Monitor for creation of scheduled tasks and registry keys associated with unknown DLL names
Detect anomalous PowerShell activity and custom C2 traffic patterns
Enforce strict URL filtering and CAPTCHA verification to prevent ClickFix lure execution
Conduct threat hunting for NOROBOT, YESROBOT, and MAYBEROBOT artifacts (file hashes, IOC strings)
Rotate credentials and limit privileged access for high‑value accounts
Deploy network segmentation to limit lateral movement from compromised hosts
references: SecurityAffairs article "Russia-linked COLDRIVER speeds up malware evolution after LOSTKEYS exposure" (2025-10-22)
