threat_actors.original_title: SIMCARTEL operation: Europol takes down SIM-Box ring linked to 3,200 scams
threat_actors.content_snippet: Europol’s SIMCARTEL operation shut down a SIM-box network behind 3,200 frauds and €4.5M losses, using 40,000 SIMs for scams and extortion. Europol’s “SIMCARTEL” operation dismantled an illegal SIM-box network tied to over 3,200 fraud cases and €4.5M in losses. The service used 1,200 SIM-boxes with 4...
primary_objectives: Provide disposable phone numbers for anonymity
Enable large‑scale phishing, smishing and fraud
Support creation of fraudulent online accounts
tactics: Operate SIM‑box infrastructure to route SMS/voice
Bulk acquisition of SIM cards worldwide
Offer phone‑number rental as a service (aaS)
techniques: T1090 – Proxy (SIM‑box as a proxy for communications)
T1584 – Obtain Capabilities: custom SIM‑box hardware
T1499 – Endpoint Denial of Service (mass account creation overload)
attack_patterns: Mass account creation for fraudulent services
Extortion scams using spoofed caller ID
procedures: Purchase thousands of SIM cards from retail outlets in 80+ countries
Load SIMs into 1,200 SIM‑box devices
Expose an API/web portal (gogetsms.com, apisim.com) for number rental
Provide payment via crypto wallets and bank transfers
Log and sell usage data to criminal clients
Rotate numbers to avoid carrier detection
victimology: Businesses losing money to investment and marketplace fraud
Victims of extortion and impersonation scams
Potential victims of child sexual abuse material distribution
known_iocs: Crypto wallet addresses (approx. $333,000 frozen) – see Europol release
SIM card batch numbers (40,000 cards seized)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 3,200 fraud cases resulting in at least €4.5 million loss in Austria and €420 k in Latvia; ~49 million fraudulent online accounts created; extensive financial, reputational, and operational damage across multiple sectors.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement carrier‑level SMS verification and number reputation services
Monitor for abnormal SMS traffic patterns and SIM‑box signatures
Enforce multi‑factor authentication that does not rely solely on SMS
Deploy rate‑limiting and anomaly detection on account creation endpoints
Educate users about smishing and phishing tactics
Collaborate with telecom operators to block bulk‑purchased SIM numbers
Track and block known rental service domains and IP ranges
Conduct regular threat‑intel sharing with law‑enforcement and industry ISACs
references: Shadowserver Foundation – seizure of gogetsms.com and apisim.com

tools: RegSvc.exe (legitimate Windows binary used for injection)
tactics: Phishing emails with malicious ZIP attachments
Use of LNK files to launch mshta.exe
AutoIt scripts for in‑memory shellcode generation
Use of GitHub repositories to host configuration files and C2 data
Persistence via LNK in startup folder
Keylogging on banking and crypto sites
techniques: T1105 – Ingress Tool Transfer (GitHub as C2)
T1547.009 – Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Shortcut Modification
attack_patterns: Use of legitimate cloud services for C2
procedures: Send phishing email with DocuSign or resume lure
Link directs victim to download ZIP containing LNK
LNK executes mshta.exe with obfuscated JavaScript
JavaScript downloads AutoIt interpreter, encrypted payload (stack.tmp), and encrypted config to ProgramData
AutoIt script builds shellcode, resolves APIs, loads Delphi DLL, decrypts final payload
Inject final Astaroth payload into newly created RegSvc.exe process
Payload monitors foreground windows for banking/crypto sites, hooks keyboard, captures credentials
Exfiltrate captured data via Ngrok tunnel
Drop LNK in startup folder for persistence
victimology: Individuals and small‑to‑medium businesses in South America and Iberian Peninsula who use online banking or cryptocurrency services
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential financial loss from stolen banking credentials, unauthorized transactions, and fraud; exposure of personal data; increased risk of follow‑on attacks.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement robust email security filtering and user awareness training to detect phishing attempts.
Block execution of mshta.exe and restrict LNK file execution from unknown sources.
Disable or monitor AutoIt interpreter usage on endpoints.
Enforce least‑privilege execution policies and application whitelisting.
Monitor outbound traffic to GitHub and Ngrok domains; consider blocking Ngrok if not required.
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions capable of detecting in‑memory shellcode and DLL injection.
Enforce multi‑factor authentication for banking and cryptocurrency platforms.
Regularly review and clean startup folder shortcuts; use OS hardening guides to prevent unauthorized LNK persistence.
Apply network segmentation to limit the impact of compromised credentials.

threat_actors.name: Unknown (Shai-Hulud malware author)
threat_actors.title: Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero
threat_actors.original_title: Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction The modern development world is almost entirely dependent on third-party modules. While this certainly speeds up development, it also creates a massive attack surface for end users, since anyone can create these components. It is no surprise that malicious modules are becoming more comm...
tactics: Supply chain compromise via npm package publishing
Credential theft from npm and GitHub tokens
Abuse of GitHub Actions for data exfiltration
Use of legitimate open‑source tools (TruffleHog, AWS SDK, GCP SDK) to hide activity
techniques: T1195.003 – Supply Chain Compromise: Package Repository
T1555.003 – Credentials from Web Browsers (GitHub token extraction)
T1566.001 – Phishing via compromised package metadata (indirect)
T1564.001 – Disk Write (temporary bash scripts in /tmp)
attack_patterns: Credential harvesting from npm and GitHub tokens
Automated creation of malicious GitHub Actions workflows
Self‑propagation by modifying and republishing popular packages
procedures: Inject malicious postinstall/preinstall script (node bundle.js) into package.json
Publish new malicious version of compromised packages using stolen npm token
Create GitHub branches and GitHub Actions workflows to harvest repository secrets
Upload exfiltrated data to attacker‑controlled webhook and to a newly created GitHub repo named "Shai-Hulud"
Use TruffleHog and cloud SDKs to locate additional secrets on the host
victimology: Enterprises with CI/CD pipelines using npm
Developers with npm and GitHub credentials stored on workstations
Organizations hosting private repositories on GitHub
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Massive compromise of over 500 npm packages, exposure of private source code and cloud credentials, potential financial loss from credential abuse, and widespread supply‑chain contamination affecting millions of downstream developers.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement automated monitoring of npm registry for newly published or updated packages.
Enforce least‑privilege npm and GitHub token scopes; rotate tokens regularly.
Audit GitHub repositories for unknown branches, workflows, and repositories named "shai-hulud".
Use SCA (Software Composition Analysis) tools to detect malicious package versions.
Apply runtime protection that blocks execution of unknown postinstall scripts.
Enable multi‑factor authentication and secret scanning on code hosting platforms.
Isolate build environments and restrict network egress for CI/CD pipelines.
references: Securelist – "Massive npm infection: the Shai-Hulud worm and patient zero" (2025-09-25)

Use SCA (Software Composition Analysis) tools to detect compromised dependencies
Apply runtime protection (EDR/XDR) to detect execution of unknown bundle.js scripts

Educate maintainers about supply‑chain security and credential hygiene

threat_actors.name: RaccoonO365
threat_actors.title: Disrupted phishing service was after Microsoft 365 credentials
threat_actors.original_title: Disrupted phishing service was after Microsoft 365 credentials
threat_actors.content_snippet: Microsoft and Cloudflare have disrupted a Phishing-as-a-Service operation, known as RaccoonO365. The primary goal of RaccoonO365 (or Storm-2246 as Microsoft calls it) was to rent out a phishing toolkit that specialized in stealing Microsoft 365 credentials. They were successful in at least 5,000 cas...
primary_objectives: harvest authentication cookies and session data
provide initial access for ransomware or other attacks
tactics: Credential harvesting via fake O365 login pages
Use of CAPTCHA and anti‑bot techniques to evade analysis
Leveraging legitimate cloud services (Cloudflare Workers) to hide infrastructure
Distribution of malicious attachments with links or QR codes
techniques: T1059 – Command and Scripting Interpreter (used for automation of credential delivery)
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
procedures: Send bulk email (up to 9,000 targets per day) with attachment containing malicious link or QR code
Victim solves CAPTCHA, is redirected to cloned Microsoft O365 login page
Captured credentials and cookies are stored on backend servers
Customers purchase 30‑day access to the kit for $355 in cryptocurrency
Kit provides harvested MFA codes to bypass two‑factor authentication
Stolen credentials are sold to downstream actors for data theft, fraud, or ransomware deployment
victimology: Organizations and individuals using Microsoft 365 (Outlook, OneDrive, SharePoint)
Employees with privileged access to corporate data
known_iocs: 338 seized domains/URLs associated with RaccoonO365 (specific domains not disclosed in article)
Telegram group with >850 members used for coordination and payment
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 5,000 compromised Microsoft 365 accounts across 94 countries, providing attackers with credentials to exfiltrate data, conduct financial fraud, extortion, and serve as footholds for ransomware. Estimated revenue for the operators exceeded $100,000 in cryptocurrency.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce phishing‑resistant MFA (e.g., FIDO2, hardware tokens)
Deploy email security gateways with attachment and link sandboxing
Implement URL filtering and block known phishing domains
Educate users to verify sender addresses and avoid clicking unsolicited attachments or links
Use password managers that do not auto‑fill credentials on untrusted sites
Monitor for anomalous sign‑in activity and impossible travel in Azure AD
Apply conditional access policies to require additional verification for high‑risk sign‑ins
Regularly rotate Microsoft 365 credentials and revoke compromised accounts promptly
references: Malwarebytes article – Disrupted phishing service was after Microsoft 365 credentials (2025-09-18)
Microsoft Digital Crimes Unit press release

Some AI chatbots are just so user friendly that they can help the user craft phishing text, and even malicious HTML and Javascript code. A few weeks a...

Iteratively refine urgency and tone based on AI suggestions
Use AI‑generated malicious HTML/JS to embed in phishing pages or attachments

Harvest credentials or install banking trojans after victim interaction

threat_actors.content_snippet: At least 18 popular JavaScript code packages that are collectively downloaded more than two billion times each week were briefly compromised with malicious software today, after a developer involved in maintaining the projects was phished. The attack appears to have been quickly contained and was na...
primary_objectives: compromise supply chain of JavaScript packages
tools: Dynamic DNS service (dnsexit.com) for domain hosting
techniques: Spear‑phishing with spoofed NPM login page
Use of one‑time 2FA token to bypass authentication
Modification of NPM package source code
Injection of JavaScript that rewrites payment destinations
attack_patterns: Supply chain compromise via open‑source package manager
procedures: Send targeted email mimicking NPM security notice
Redirect victim to fake NPM login site
Capture credentials and 2FA token
Change account email to lock out legitimate owner
Publish malicious version of popular packages using compromised account
victimology: Web applications that depend on compromised NPM packages
known_iocs: dnsexit.com (dynamic DNS provider used for spoofed site)

Implement code signing and provenance verification for high‑profile NPM packages

Limit the number of maintainers with publish rights and enforce least‑privilege principles

threat_actors.original_title: Hackers breached Salesloft ’s GitHub in March, and used stole tokens in a mass attack
threat_actors.content_snippet: Hackers breached Salesloft’s GitHub in March, stole tokens, and used them in a mass attack on several major tech customers. Salesloft revealed that the threat actor UNC6395 breached its GitHub account in March, stealing authentication tokens that were later used in a large-scale attack against sever...
primary_objectives: Maintain persistent access to SaaS environments
tactics: Initial Access via compromised GitHub credentials
procedures: Compromise of GitHub organization account
Download of multiple repositories
Addition of a guest user and creation of CI/CD workflows
Access to AWS environment linked to Drift platform
Harvesting of OAuth tokens for Drift customers
Use of stolen tokens to access integrated SaaS services
threat_actors.impact_assessment: The breach resulted in the theft of OAuth tokens used by multiple high‑profile technology customers, enabling unauthorized data access and potential exposure of sensitive information. Service disruption occurred for the Drift platform, and the incident highlighted significant gaps in credential management and segmentation, leading to a six‑month detection window.
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce MFA on all GitHub and cloud service accounts
Implement secret scanning and token revocation policies in repositories
Rotate all OAuth tokens and API keys immediately after detection
Apply strict least‑privilege IAM policies and network segmentation between SaaS platforms
Monitor for anomalous GitHub activity such as guest user additions and workflow changes
Deploy continuous credential‑access monitoring and alerting for token misuse
Conduct regular supply‑chain risk assessments for third‑party integrations
references: SecurityAffairs – "Hackers breached Salesloft’s GitHub in March, and used stole tokens in a mass attack" (2025-09-08)
Mandiant investigation report on UNC6395 activity (2025)

threat_actors.original_title: Scammers mass-mailing the Efimer Trojan to steal crypto
threat_actors.content_snippet: Introduction In June, we encountered a mass mailing campaign impersonating lawyers from a major company. These emails falsely claimed the recipient’s domain name infringed on the sender’s rights. The messages contained the Efimer malicious script, designed to steal cryptocurrency. This s...
primary_objectives: steal cryptocurrency wallet credentials and funds
exfiltrate email addresses for future spam/phishing
tactics: Use of Tor for C2 anonymity
Clipboard hijacking and wallet address replacement
Credential brute‑forcing of WordPress admin accounts
Persistence via scheduled tasks and Run registry key
techniques: T1562.004 – Disable or Modify Security Tools
T1041 – Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
T1027 – Obfuscated Files or Information (Unicode password filename)
attack_patterns: Use of Tor hidden services for C2
procedures: Send ZIP archive with password‑protected inner archive; password file uses Unicode look‑alike character
WSF script (Requirement.wsf) drops controller.js and controller.xml to C:\Users\Public\controller
Add Windows Defender exclusion for the controller folder and related binaries
Create scheduled task (privileged) or add Run key (limited) for persistence
Download Tor client from multiple hard‑coded URLs and launch via WScript
Generate or read GUID stored in C:\Users\Public\controller\GUID
Periodically ping Onion C2 (every 30 min) and process EVAL commands
Capture clipboard, replace detected crypto addresses with attacker‑controlled ones, exfiltrate via Tor
Take five screenshots via PowerShell and exfiltrate
Brute‑force WordPress logins using word lists harvested from Wikipedia, report results to C2
Harvest email addresses from target sites (Liame script) and send to C2 for spam use
victimology: Windows desktop users who open email attachments or download torrents
Administrators of poorly secured WordPress sites
Cryptocurrency holders using clipboard copy/paste for wallet addresses
Enterprises with employees using corporate email for domain‑related communications
known_iocs: Password file name contains Unicode character U+1D5E6
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 5,000 Kaspersky detections across multiple countries, resulting in direct theft of cryptocurrency funds, compromise of WordPress sites, and creation of large email address databases for future spam/phishing. The modular nature of the malware enables continued distribution and expansion of the botnet.
mitigation_recommendations: Block execution of .wsf and .js scripts from unknown sources
Disable or tightly control use of PowerShell and curl for outbound connections
Enforce multi‑factor authentication and strong, unique passwords on all WordPress installations
Regularly update WordPress core, plugins, and themes; remove unused plugins
Monitor for and block outbound traffic to known Tor onion domains
Implement email security gateways that scan for password‑protected archives and Unicode obfuscation
Educate users not to open unexpected attachments or download torrents from untrusted sites
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions that can detect clipboard hijacking behavior
Audit scheduled tasks and Run registry keys for unknown entries
Configure Windows Defender (or equivalent) to disallow user‑added exclusions without admin approval
references: Securelist – "Scammers mass‑mailing the Efimer Trojan to steal crypto" (2025‑08‑08)

threat_actors.name: Modded Fire TV Stick Operators

threat_actors.original_title: The hidden costs of illegal streaming and modded Amazon Fire TV Sticks
threat_actors.content_snippet: Ahead of the holiday season, people who have bought cheap Amazon Fire TV Sticks or similar devices online should be aware that some of them could let cybercriminals access personal data, bank accounts, and even steal money. BeStreamWise, a UK initiative established to counter illegal streaming, says...
tactics: Supply chain compromise of low‑cost streaming hardware
Pre‑installation of malicious or pirated applications
Use of USB/OTG interfaces to deliver payloads
Social engineering to lure victims into installing unauthorized apps
techniques: T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter (custom scripts in malicious apps)
T1056 - Input Capture (keylogging for banking credentials)
T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service (disabling legitimate streaming services)
attack_patterns: Credential Harvesting via malicious streaming apps
Identity theft via collection of personal data
procedures: Purchase bulk low‑cost Fire TV sticks from unverified sellers
Flash modified firmware or side‑load unauthorized APKs
Bundle spyware/banking trojan with pirated streaming apps
Distribute devices via online marketplaces and social media groups
Monetize through direct fraud, credential resale, and ransomware extortion
victimology: Consumers purchasing cheap or second‑hand streaming sticks
Individuals seeking free access to premium media content
Users with weak device security hygiene
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Victims reported average financial losses of £1,700 (~$2,230) per incident, along with identity theft and potential long‑term credit damage. The campaign also undermines legitimate streaming services and contributes to broader cyber‑crime economy.
mitigation_recommendations: Avoid purchasing or using unverified streaming devices
Disable autorun/autoplay on all computers and TV platforms
Mount external USB devices in read‑only mode where possible
Run up‑to‑date anti‑malware scans on any newly connected hardware
Enable multi‑factor authentication on all financial and personal accounts
Monitor bank and credit statements for unauthorized activity
Educate users about the risks of illegal streaming services

primary_objectives: deploy ransomware (Rhysida, INC, BlackCat, Quantum Locker, Zeppelin)
tactics: Distribution of fake Microsoft Teams installers
SEO poisoning to drive traffic to malicious download sites
Abuse of legitimate code‑signing certificates (Trusted Signing, SSL.com, DigiCert, GlobalSign)
Use of Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) for lateral movement
Execution of payloads via Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)
techniques: T1195 – Supply Chain Compromise (fraudulent code signing)
procedures: Host malicious MSTeamsSetup.exe on domains that resemble official Teams URLs (e.g., teams-download.buzz, teams-install.run)
Lure victims via search‑engine results that point to the fake download pages
Sign the installer and post‑compromise tools with stolen or fraudulently obtained certificates
When executed, the installer drops a loader that installs the Oyster backdoor
Backdoor is used to deliver ransomware families such as Rhysida, INC, BlackCat, Quantum Locker, and Zeppelin
Use compromised RDP credentials to move laterally across the network
Leverage WMI to execute ransomware payloads on remote hosts
campaigns: Vanilla Tempest fake Teams installer campaign (Oct 2025)
known_iocs: Over 200 revoked code‑signing certificates (Microsoft revocation list)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Widespread deployment of ransomware leading to data encryption, operational downtime, potential data exfiltration, and significant financial losses for affected organizations.
mitigation_recommendations: Enable Microsoft Defender Antivirus and Defender for Endpoint with latest IoC feeds
Block execution of unsigned or suspiciously signed binaries
Implement strict RDP access controls (network segmentation, MFA, jump hosts)
Monitor for newly issued code‑signing certificates and revocation events
Educate users about SEO poisoning and verify software sources before download
Apply application whitelisting and endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions
Regularly back up critical data and test restore procedures
Monitor WMI activity for anomalous command execution
references: SecurityAffairs article: Microsoft revokes 200+ certificates abused by Vanilla Tempest in fake Teams campaign (2025-10-17)

Deploy Cobalt Strike beacons for command and control

Compress and upload stolen data to services such as Google Drive, OneDrive, or Dropbox

Rapid infrastructure rotation to evade takedown

Exploitation of Trust in Legitimate Domains (T1190)

Deploy web‑gateway URL filtering and reputation services

Regularly review and rotate credentials for compromised accounts

threat_actors.content_snippet: The North Korean threat actors behind the Contagious Interview campaign have continued to flood the npm registry with 197 more malicious packages since last month. According to Socket, these packages have been downloaded over 31,000 times, and are designed to deliver a variant of OtterCookie that br...
primary_objectives: Distribute malicious payloads via compromised npm packages
Exfiltrate data and conduct further operations
techniques: T1195.009 - Supply Chain Compromise: Package Repository
attack_patterns: Supply chain attack via npm registry
procedures: Create and publish malicious npm packages that appear legitimate
Embed OtterCookie/BeaverTail payloads within package scripts
Leverage npm install process to execute malicious code
Use code obfuscation and anti-analysis techniques
victimology: Organizations that depend on npm packages
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Over 31,000 downloads of 197 malicious packages, potentially leading to widespread infection of development environments and downstream production systems.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement strict npm package vetting and use signed packages where possible
Enable npm audit and continuously monitor for newly published packages with similar naming patterns
Apply runtime protection and behavior monitoring for Node.js processes
Restrict execution of post‑install scripts in npm (use --ignore-scripts flag when appropriate)
Adopt software composition analysis (SCA) tools to detect malicious dependencies
Educate developers on supply‑chain risks and encourage use of private registries for critical projects
references: Socket security report on Contagious Interview campaign

threat_actors.name: Atomic Stealer Group
threat_actors.title: Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware
threat_actors.original_title: Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware
threat_actors.content_snippet: Fake versions of legitimate software are currently circulating on GitHub pages, in a large-scale campaign targeting Mac users. Unfortunately, Malwarebytes for Mac is one of them. Impersonating brands is sadly commonplace, as scammers take advantage of established brand names to target their victims....
primary_objectives: collection of personal and financial data
monetization via resale of harvested credentials
tactics: Social engineering via fake software pages
Command‑line execution of remote scripts (curl | bash)
techniques: T1547 Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
attack_patterns: Fake software distribution via compromised GitHub pages
Direct execution of remote scripts via curl | bash
procedures: Create a GitHub repository mimicking a legitimate macOS application
Publish a “GET MALWAREBYTES” button linking to a download page
Provide a copy‑pasted Bash one‑liner that fetches and executes a remote script
Host the malicious script on a newly registered domain (e.g., gosreestr.com)
Use base64‑encoded URLs to obscure the download link
Deploy the Atomic Stealer (AMOS) payload to harvest credentials and system data
victimology: MacOS end users searching for security or productivity software
Individuals using password managers and finance‑related apps
known_iocs: GitHub pages hosting fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, 1Password, etc.
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential large‑scale credential theft affecting thousands of Mac users, leading to financial fraud, account takeover, and secondary resale of compromised data.
mitigation_recommendations: Never execute copy‑pasted curl | bash commands from unverified sources
Download software only from official vendor websites or verified app stores
Block or flag sponsored search results and SEO‑manipulated listings
Enable real‑time anti‑malware with web protection on macOS
Monitor for unknown LaunchAgents/LaunchDaemons in /Library/LaunchAgents and /Library/LaunchDaemons
Conduct regular credential hygiene: change passwords and enable MFA after suspected compromise
Use DNS filtering to block known malicious domains (e.g., gosreestr.com)
references: Malwarebytes Blog – Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware (2025-09-23)
LastPass Threat Intelligence – GitHub impersonation campaign

tactics: Impersonation of legitimate software on GitHub
Social engineering via copy‑paste command execution
Use of curl | bash command chains

procedures: Publish fake GitHub repository mimicking popular apps
Provide a “GET <product>” button linking to a malicious download page
Distribute a one‑liner Bash command that decodes a base64 URL and pipes it to curl and bash
Host the final payload on a newly‑registered domain (e.g., gosreestr.com)
Leverage legitimate‑looking branding to encourage copy‑paste execution
victimology: Mac users searching for security, productivity, or finance software
Individuals and small businesses downloading software from unofficial sources
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential theft of credentials, personal data, and financial information; may lead to unauthorized account access and monetary loss for victims.

Download software only from official vendor websites or verified app stores.
Avoid clicking sponsored search results or ads that redirect to third‑party pages.
Enable real‑time anti‑malware protection with web‑filtering capabilities.
Regularly audit macOS LaunchAgents, LaunchDaemons, and login items for unknown entries.
Perform periodic credential changes and enable multi‑factor authentication.
Educate users about SEO poisoning and the risks of unofficial GitHub repositories.
references: Malwarebytes Blog – Fake Malwarebytes, LastPass, and others on GitHub serve malware (2025‑09‑23)
LastPass Threat Intelligence – GitHub Impersonation Campaign

threat_actors.content_snippet: Phishers and scammers can’t get enough of sending their feeble attempts to Malwarebytes’ employees. For which we can’t thank them enough because it means we can warn you, our readers. This time the scammers tried to impersonate Best Wallet—an app that lets people store, send, and receive cryptocurre...
primary_objectives: steal cryptocurrency private keys, seed phrases, and payment details
obtain unauthorized access to crypto wallets
procedures: Send unsolicited text messages with shortened malicious URLs
Host a replica of the legitimate Best Wallet site behind a captcha
Present a deceptive ‘Connect a Wallet’ button to harvest wallet credentials
Inject JavaScript to capture or modify user inputs during wallet connection
known_iocs: shortened URL used in phishing messages (specific URL not disclosed)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential loss of cryptocurrency assets ranging from small individual balances to large holdings, depending on victim wallet value; reputational damage to the Best Wallet brand.
mitigation_recommendations: Never click on unsolicited links in SMS or email messages; verify URLs manually.
Use hardware wallets or reputable wallet apps that do not allow web-based private key entry.
Enable anti-phishing and web protection features on endpoints.
Educate users about the risks of connecting wallets via browsers and the legitimacy of app‑store only installations.
Deploy URL filtering to block known malicious domains and shorteners.
Report suspicious messages to security teams or services like Malwarebytes Scam Guard.
references: Malwarebytes article: “Don’t connect your wallet: Best Wallet cryptocurrency scam is making the rounds” (2025-10-07)

threat_actors.name: Radiant
threat_actors.title: From threats to apology, hackers pull child data offline after public backlash
threat_actors.original_title: From threats to apology, hackers pull child data offline after public backlash
threat_actors.content_snippet: Last week we yelled at some “hackers” that threatened parents after stealing data from their children’s nursery. This followed a BBC report that a group calling itself “Radiant” claimed to have stolen sensitive data related to around 8,000 children from nursery chain Kido, which operates in th...
tactics: initial access broker (IAB) purchase for foothold
public leaking of sample data on darknet site
direct threatening phone calls to parents
ransom demand with threat of further data release
post‑breach data removal and public apology
techniques: use of darknet hosting for data publication
procedures: purchase of access from an IAB
download and exfiltrate child and employee records
publish sample records (photos, profiles) to prove possession
issue ransom note demanding payment to stop further leaks
escalate threat by adding more records
contact victims directly to pressure payment
after public backlash, blur images, take data offline, issue apology
victimology: children enrolled in Kido nursery chain
campaigns: Radiant Kido Child Data Extortion Campaign
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Exposure of personal data for ~8,000 children and dozens of employees, including photos, profiles, National Insurance numbers, and contact details. Resulted in reputational damage to Kido, emotional distress for families, potential for identity theft and fraud, and heightened public scrutiny of the threat actor.
mitigation_recommendations: Change all compromised passwords and enforce strong, unique passwords
Enable multi‑factor authentication, preferably FIDO2 hardware keys
Monitor for credential leakage and identity theft using identity monitoring services
Educate parents and staff about phishing and social‑engineering phone scams
Conduct a thorough forensic investigation to confirm the extent of the breach
Implement network segmentation and least‑privilege access controls to limit data exposure
Regularly audit third‑party access and verify the legitimacy of any IAB relationships

threat_actors.name: FBI Impersonation Scam Syndicates
threat_actors.title: Scammers are impersonating the FBI to steal your personal data
threat_actors.original_title: Scammers are impersonating the FBI to steal your personal data
threat_actors.content_snippet: Been scammed? Hoping to report it to the FBI? Definitely do so, but be careful. Spoofed versions of the FBI’s Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) website are now circulating online, and they lead straight back to the scammers. The FBI issued an advisory last week, warning that cybercriminals...
tools: Caller ID spoofing platforms (e.g., SpoofCard, BluffCaller)
techniques: T1566.002 - Phishing: Spearphishing Link (fake IC3 URL)
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1071.003 - Application Layer Protocol: Mail Protocols
T1036.005 - Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
attack_patterns: Credential Harvesting via Fake Government Portal
Secondary Fraud Targeting Victims of Prior Scams
Phone‑Based Extortion Using Spoofed Law‑Enforcement Numbers
procedures: Create look‑alike domains that differ by one or two characters from ic3.gov
Distribute malicious URLs via social media, email, or direct messages to recent fraud victims
Prompt victims to enter personally identifying information and banking details on the fake portal
Follow up with phone calls using spoofed caller ID or AI‑generated voice to request additional funds or verification
Monetize harvested data through resale on underground markets or direct fraudulent transactions
victimology: Individuals who have recently filed an IC3 report
Victims emotionally distressed after a prior fraud incident
known_iocs: Email subjects: "Your IC3 Report – Action Required", "Funds Recovered – Verify Your Identity"
Phone number prefixes: Spoofed 202‑***‑**** (FBI) or 800‑***‑**** (government hotlines)
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Harvested personal and financial data leading to secondary monetary loss; increased victim distrust of legitimate reporting channels; potential for large‑scale credential reuse attacks.
mitigation_recommendations: Always access IC3 via the official URL typed directly into the browser or bookmarked link.
Educate users to verify government domains (e.g., .gov TLD) and look for subtle misspellings.
Deploy anti‑phishing email gateways and web filtering for known typosquatted domains.
Use multi‑factor authentication on any accounts where personal data is stored.
Encourage victims to report secondary scams to the real IC3 and law enforcement promptly.
Implement caller‑ID verification and train staff to recognize voice‑cloned vishing attempts.
references: FBI Advisory – Impersonation of FBI IC3 (2025-09-16)
Malwarebytes article – Scammers are impersonating the FBI to steal your personal data (2025-09-23)

procedures: register look‑alike domains (e.g., ic3‑gov.com, ic3online.net)

distribute malicious links via email, social media, and phone calls
follow up with victims of prior scams to extract additional data
victimology: individuals who have filed IC3 reports

Leverage threat intelligence feeds that flag known IC3‑related phishing domains.
Encourage victims to report secondary scams promptly to the real IC3 portal.
references: Malwarebytes article – "Scammers are impersonating the FBI to steal your personal data" (2025-09-23)

threat_actors.name: Unnamed cybercriminal group
threat_actors.title: How AI-Native Development Platforms Enable Fake Captcha Pages
threat_actors.original_title: How AI-Native Development Platforms Enable Fake Captcha Pages
threat_actors.content_snippet: Cybercriminals are abusing AI-native platforms like Vercel, Netlify, and Lovable to host fake captcha pages that deceive users, bypass detection, and drive phishing campaigns.
primary_objectives: Monetize via fraud or credential resale
tactics: Abuse of AI-native cloud hosting platforms
Deployment of fake captcha pages to lure users
Obfuscation of malicious infrastructure through legitimate services
techniques: T1190 – Exploit Public-Facing Application (used to compromise victim sites that serve captchas)
T1105 – Ingress Tool Transfer (upload of malicious pages to Vercel/Netlify)
T1071.001 – Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
procedures: Create a subdomain on Vercel, Netlify, or Lovable
Deploy a static HTML/JS page that mimics a legitimate captcha challenge
Redirect legitimate traffic to the fake captcha page via compromised sites or malicious ads
Collect entered data (email, passwords, 2FA codes) and forward to command‑and‑control server
Rotate domains and hosting accounts to evade takedown
victimology: End‑users visiting compromised or maliciously advertised websites
Users attempting to solve captchas on high‑traffic consumer sites
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Potential credential theft, unauthorized account access, financial fraud, and reputational damage to compromised websites.
mitigation_recommendations: Implement multi‑factor authentication to reduce impact of credential theft
Monitor DNS and SSL certificates for newly registered subdomains on Vercel, Netlify, and similar platforms
Deploy anti‑phishing solutions that inspect page content for fake captcha patterns
Educate users to verify the legitimacy of captcha challenges and avoid entering credentials on unexpected pages
Use web‑application firewalls (WAF) to block redirects to known malicious hosting domains
references: TrendMicro – How AI‑Native Development Platforms Enable Fake Captcha Pages (2025-09-19)

threat_actors.name: AI-Platform Abuse Group
threat_actors.title: How AI-Native Development Platforms Enable Fake Captcha Pages
threat_actors.original_title: How AI-Native Development Platforms Enable Fake Captcha Pages
threat_actors.content_snippet: Cybercriminals are abusing AI-native platforms like Vercel, Netlify, and Lovable to host fake captcha pages that deceive users, bypass detection, and drive phishing campaigns.
tactics: Use of legitimate cloud hosting services to evade detection
Obfuscation of malicious pages behind legitimate-looking captchas
techniques: T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application (hosting fake pages on Vercel/Netlify)
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter (JavaScript for dynamic captcha generation)
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer (uploading malicious scripts to hosting platforms)
attack_patterns: Abuse of serverless hosting for malicious content
procedures: Create a fake login page that includes a CAPTCHA challenge hosted on Vercel, Netlify, or Lovable
Obtain a short-lived domain or subdomain from the platform and point it to the malicious page
Distribute phishing emails or malicious ads that direct victims to the fake CAPTCHA page
Capture entered credentials and CAPTCHA solutions, then forward them to command‑and‑control infrastructure
victimology: Users of online services that require CAPTCHA verification
Employees of targeted organizations receiving phishing emails

mitigation_recommendations: Implement multi‑factor authentication (MFA) for all privileged accounts
Educate users to verify URL authenticity before entering credentials
Deploy anti‑phishing email gateways with URL rewriting detection
Monitor DNS queries and traffic to newly registered subdomains on Vercel, Netlify, and similar platforms
Use threat intelligence feeds that flag known malicious subdomains on serverless hosting services

threat_actors.name: Unnamed cybercriminal group
threat_actors.title: Supply chain attack targets npm, +2 Billion weekly npm downloads exposed
threat_actors.original_title: Supply chain attack targets npm, +2 Billion weekly npm downloads exposed
threat_actors.content_snippet: Multiple popular npm packages were compromised in a supply chain attack after a maintainer fell for a phishing email targeting 2FA credentials. A supply chain attack compromised multiple popular npm packages with 2B weekly downloads after a maintainer fell for a phishing email mimicking npm, targeti...
primary_objectives: publish malicious versions of popular packages
tactics: cryptocurrency theft via JavaScript API interception
techniques: Code Injection – malicious JavaScript in index.js (T1059.007)
attack_patterns: Supply chain compromise via compromised maintainer credentials
procedures: Send phishing email from spoofed address support@npmjs.help urging 2FA update
Redirect victim to credential‑stealing web page requesting username, password, and 2FA token
Use harvested credentials to log into npm account and publish compromised package versions
Inject malicious code that hooks fetch, XMLHttpRequest, and common crypto‑wallet APIs to rewrite destination addresses
Publish malicious packages under existing popular names (e.g., chalk, debug, ansi‑styles)
victimology: Open‑source maintainers with npm publishing rights
Developers and organizations consuming compromised npm packages
End‑users of applications that integrate the malicious packages
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Compromised ~20 high‑profile npm packages with >2 billion weekly downloads, enabling potential theft of cryptocurrency funds from any downstream application that uses the injected wallet‑interception code. Also caused loss of trust in npm ecosystem and required extensive remediation (package version verification, cache clearing, dependency pinning).
mitigation_recommendations: Enforce hardware‑based 2FA (U2F/FIDO2) for npm accounts
Monitor npm account activity and enable login alerts
Adopt npm package signing (npm audit, provenance) and verify signatures
Use lockfiles (package‑lock.json, yarn.lock) with pinned exact versions
Regularly audit dependencies with tools like npm audit, Snyk, or OSS‑index
Implement CI/CD checks that compare published package hashes against known good values
Educate maintainers on phishing awareness and verify any 2FA update requests via official channels
Isolate and sandbox third‑party JavaScript dependencies
Maintain an internal allow‑list of approved npm packages and versions
references: SecurityAffairs article – Supply chain attack targets npm, +2 Billion weekly npm downloads exposed (2025‑09‑09)
Aikido Security analysis of malicious npm packages (2025‑09‑09)

threat_actors.name: Unattributed cybercriminal group (AMOS campaign)
threat_actors.title: Google ads funnel Mac users to poisoned AI chats that spread the AMOS infostealer
threat_actors.original_title: Google ads funnel Mac users to poisoned AI chats that spread the AMOS infostealer
threat_actors.content_snippet: Researchers have found evidence that AI conversations were inserted in Google search results to mislead macOS users into installing the Atomic macOS Stealer (AMOS). Both Grok and ChatGPT were found to have been abused in these attacks. Forensic investigation of an AMOS alert showed the infection cha...
tactics: Social engineering via malicious AI conversation links
techniques: T1547.001 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution (LaunchAgents/LaunchDaemons)
T1566.002 - Phishing: Spearphishing Link (malicious AI chat link)
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution (use of AI‑generated URLs)
procedures: Create a crafted prompt for ChatGPT or Grok to generate a step‑by‑step “cleanup” guide that includes a malicious curl | bash command.
Publish the curated conversation via the AI platform’s sharing feature, producing a short public link.
Promote the link through paid Google ads or SEO‑optimized pages so that searches like “clear disk space on macOS” return the malicious conversation.
Victim follows the instructions, copies the curl | bash command into Terminal.
The command decodes a base64 string that points to a malicious bash script hosted on a remote server.
The script installs the AMOS (Atomic macOS Stealer) malware, which harvests credentials, escalates privileges, and creates persistence via LaunchAgents/Daemons.
victimology: macOS users searching for disk‑cleanup or software installation guidance
campaigns: Google ads funnel Mac users to poisoned AI chats (AMOS campaign)
known_iocs: Base64‑encoded payload embedded in the Terminal command
threat_actors.impact_assessment: Victims may suffer credential theft, financial loss from cryptocurrency wallet compromise, and long‑term persistence on their macOS devices requiring full system reinstall.
mitigation_recommendations: Avoid clicking on sponsored search results; verify advertiser identity before interacting.
Do not execute copy‑pasted commands from untrusted sources, especially curl | bash pipelines.
Enable real‑time anti‑malware protection with web‑filtering capabilities on macOS.
Monitor and regularly audit LaunchAgents and LaunchDaemons for unknown entries.
Educate users about the risks of trusting AI‑generated instructions without verification.
Implement application allowlisting (e.g., using macOS Gatekeeper or third‑party solutions).
Enforce multi‑factor authentication and rotate passwords after suspected compromise.

Decode recipient addresses to reconstruct original seed phrase
In‑memory operation to avoid plaintext network traffic
